('77', 56, 6, 22, 106393) 72. UNCONDITIONAL SUPPORT ?
('77', 56, 7, 23, 106421) Several British friends are puzzled and ask “Have you really said, you will give unconditional support to Great Britain as you are reported to have said?” The origin of this report lies in my very first statement 3 after my talk 4 with the Viceroy.
('77', 56, 7, 24, 106670) The phrase ‘unconditional
('77', 56, 8, 25, 106696) 1 According to the addressee, the letter was written some time in October 1939. The addressee, who had gone to Bihar to organize a women volunteer corps, came to Wardha on October 30, 1939; vide “Letter to Kanchanbehn M. Shah”, and “Letter to Shardabehn G. Chokhawala”, 30 10 1939. 2 In Bapuna patro 5: Premabehn Kantakne p.
('77', 56, 8, 26, 107021) 270, the addressee explains: “In view of the world war, the Congress Working Committee passed a resolution that ahimsa could not retain its primary place in the party’s programme.’ 3 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 5 9 1939. 4 On September 4 at Simla
('77', 57, 0, 1, 107271) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('77', 57, 1, 2, 107312) support’ does not occur in that statement.
('77', 57, 1, 3, 107355) But had the Congress appreciated the position I took up, Congress support would have been unconditional in the sense that the Congress would not have asked for a clarification of Britain’s war aims.
('77', 57, 1, 4, 107554) But the Working Committee could not honestly take up that position.
('77', 57, 1, 5, 107622) Therefore it passed as it had every right and justification for passing, the resolution 1 it did.
('77', 57, 1, 6, 107720) Events have shown the prudence of the course adopted by the Working Committee.
('77', 57, 1, 7, 107799) But had it waived the demand for the declaration of war aims, the support would have been unconditional.
('77', 57, 1, 8, 107904) Remember, according to its constitution, the Congress is a non violent body.
('77', 57, 1, 9, 107981) Therefore its support would have been purely moral.
('77', 57, 1, 10, 108033) It has no soldiers to supply, it has no money to give.
('77', 57, 1, 11, 108088) But it has its good wishes.
('77', 57, 1, 12, 108116) In my opinion those good wishes would have been more than many battalions.
('77', 57, 1, 13, 108191) The Congress support would have put the British cause on an unassailable moral basis.
('77', 57, 1, 14, 108277) It would have made the British case just, beyond measure.
('77', 57, 1, 15, 108335) All the dependent races of the earth would have felt an indescribable glow of freedom.
('77', 57, 1, 16, 108422) British moral stock would have shot up high at a bound.
('77', 57, 1, 17, 108478) That is what the Congress unconditional support would have meant.
('77', 57, 1, 18, 108544) But God had willed otherwise.
('77', 57, 1, 19, 108574) British statesmen had not faith enough in the Congress profession of non violence.
('77', 57, 1, 20, 108657) I must confess that the Congress could not pass the test to the satisfaction of a strict though just examiner.
('77', 57, 1, 21, 108768) Anyway my British friends should have no difficulty in understanding my position.
('77', 57, 1, 22, 108850) Of course it is open to them to argue that as a war resister I could not even give moral support.
('77', 57, 1, 23, 108948) I have already said in these columns 2 that I do not hold such a view.
('77', 57, 1, 24, 109019) It is open to a war resister to judge between two combatants and wish success to the one who has justice on his side.
('77', 57, 1, 25, 109137) By so judging he is more likely to bring peace between the two than by remaining a mere spectator.
('77', 57, 1, 26, 109236) SEGAON, October 30, 1939 Harijan, 4 11 1939
('77', 57, 2, 27, 109280) 1 Vide Appendix “Congress Working Committee Resolution”, after 18 7 1939. 2 Vide “Notes”, 16 10 1939.
('77', 58, 0, 1, 109382) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 59
('77', 58, 1, 2, 109430) 73. MY LIFE
('77', 58, 2, 3, 109442) The following from its Allahabad correspondent appears in The Bombay Chronicle:
('77', 58, 3, 4, 109522) Startling revelations have come to light regarding what has been going round the House of Commons about Gandhiji.
('77', 58, 3, 5, 109636) It is reported that Mr. Edward Thompson, the British historian who visited Allahabad recently, threw some light on the curious mentality prevailing in England.
('77', 58, 3, 6, 109796) Mr. Thompson, who met some political leaders here, is reported to have told them three things going round the House of Commons regarding Gandhiji:
('77', 58, 4, 7, 109943) 1. Gandhiji was for unconditional co operation with the British Government.
('77', 58, 5, 8, 110019) 2. Gandhiji could still influence the Congress.
('77', 58, 6, 9, 110067) 3. There were various stories about Gandhiji’s sensual life, it being the impression that Gandhiji had ceased to be a saint.
('77', 58, 7, 10, 110192) Impressions about Gandhiji’s ‘sensual life’, it appeared to Mr. Thompson, were based on some Marathi papers.
('77', 58, 7, 11, 110301) He spoke about them, I understand, to Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru, who repudiated them.
('77', 58, 7, 12, 110383) He spoke about them to Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and Mr. P. N. Sapru also, who strongly repudiated them.
('77', 58, 8, 13, 110486) It appears Mr. Thompson, before leaving England, had seen several members of the House of Commons.
('77', 58, 8, 14, 110585) Mr. Thompson, before leaving Allahabad, sent a letter to Mr. Greenwood, M.P., on the suggestion of Pandit Nehru pointing out that the stories regarding Gandhiji were absolutely baseless.
('77', 58, 8, 15, 110772) Mr. Thompson was good enough to visit Segaon.
('77', 58, 8, 16, 110818) He confirmed the report as substantially correct.
('77', 58, 8, 17, 110868) The ‘unconditional co operation’ is dealt with in another note 1. The country will presently know the influence I have over the Congress.
('77', 58, 8, 18, 111006) The third charge needs clearing.
('77', 58, 8, 19, 111039) Two days ago I received a letter signed by four or five Gujaratis sending me a newspaper whose one mission seems to be to paint me as black as it is possible for any person to be painted.
('77', 58, 8, 20, 111227) According to its headline it is a paper devoted to ‘the organization of Hindus’.
('77', 58, 8, 21, 111308) The charges against me are mostly
('77', 58, 9, 22, 111342) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('77', 59, 0, 1, 111369) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('77', 59, 1, 2, 111410) taken from my confessions and distorted from their setting.
('77', 59, 1, 3, 111470) Among many other charges, the charge of sensuality is most marked.
('77', 59, 1, 4, 111537) My brahmacharya is said to be a cloak to hide my sensuality.
('77', 59, 1, 5, 111598) Poor Dr. Sushila Nayyar has been dragged before the public gaze for the crime of giving me massage and medicated baths, the two things for which she is the best qualified among those who surround me.
('77', 59, 1, 6, 111798) The curious may be informed that there is no privacy about these operations which take over 11 2 hours and during which I often go off to sleep but during which I also transact business with Mahadev, Pyarelal or other co workers.
('77', 59, 1, 7, 112028) The charges, to my knowledge, began with my active campaign against untouchability.
('77', 59, 1, 8, 112112) This was when it was included in the Congress programme and I began to address crowds on the subject and insisted on having Harijans at meetings and in the Ashram.
('77', 59, 1, 9, 112276) It was then that some sanatanists, who used to help me and befriend me, broke with me and began a campaign of vilification.
('77', 59, 1, 10, 112400) Later, a very high placed Englishman joined the chorus.
('77', 59, 1, 11, 112456) He picked out my freedom with women and showed up my ‘saintliness’ as sinfulness.
('77', 59, 1, 12, 112538) In this chorus there were also one or two well known Indians.
('77', 59, 1, 13, 112600) During the Round Table Conference, American Journals indulged in cruel caricatures of me.
('77', 59, 1, 14, 112690) Mirabai who used to look after me was the target of their attack.
('77', 59, 1, 15, 112756) As far as I could understand Mr. Thompson, who knows the gentlemen who have been behind these charges, my letters to Premabehn Kantak, who is a member of the Sabarmati Ashram, have also been used to prove my depravity.
('77', 59, 1, 16, 112975) She is a graduate and worker of proved merit.
('77', 59, 1, 17, 113021) She used to ask questions relating to brahmacharya and other topics.
('77', 59, 1, 18, 113090) I sent her full replies 1. She thought they might be of general use and she published them with my permission.
('77', 59, 1, 19, 113201) I hold them to be absolutely innocent and pure.
('77', 59, 1, 20, 113249) Hitherto I have ignored these charges.
('77', 59, 1, 21, 113288) But Mr. Thompson’s talks about them and the importunity of the Gujarati correspondents, who say the indictment sent by them is but a sample of what is being said about me, impel me to repudiate them.
('77', 59, 1, 22, 113488) I have no secrets of my own in this life.
('77', 59, 1, 23, 113530) I have owned my weaknesses.
('77', 59, 1, 24, 113558) If I were sensually inclined, I would have the courage to make the confession.
('77', 59, 1, 25, 113637) It was when I developed detestation of sensual connection even with my own wife and had sufficiently tested myself that I took the vow of
('77', 59, 2, 26, 113775) 1 Vide “Letter to Premabehn Kantak”, 6 5 1936 and 21 5 1936; also “Letter to Premabehn Kantak”, 5 2 1937 and 25 8 1937.
('77', 60, 0, 1, 113895) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 61
('77', 60, 1, 2, 113943) brahmacharya in 1906, and that for the sake of better dedication to the service of the country.
('77', 60, 1, 3, 114039) From that day began my open life.
('77', 60, 1, 4, 114073) I do not remember having ever slept or remained with my own wife or other women with closed doors except for the occasions referred to in my writings in Young India and Navajivan.
('77', 60, 1, 5, 114253) Those were black nights with me.
('77', 60, 1, 6, 114286) But as I have said repeatedly God has saved me in spite of myself.
('77', 60, 1, 7, 114353) I claim no credit for any virtue that I may possess.
('77', 60, 1, 8, 114406) He is for me the Giver of all good and has saved me for His service.
('77', 60, 1, 9, 114475) From that day when I began brahmacharya, our freedom began.
('77', 60, 1, 10, 114535) My wife became a free woman, free from my authority as her lord and master, and I became free from my slavery to my own appetite which she had to satisfy.
('77', 60, 1, 11, 114690) No other woman had any attraction for me in the same sense that my wife had.
('77', 60, 1, 12, 114767) I was too loyal to her as husband and too loyal to the vow I had taken before my mother to be slave to any other woman.
('77', 60, 1, 13, 114887) But the manner in which my brahmacharya came to me irresistibly drew me to woman as the mother of man.
('77', 60, 1, 14, 114990) She became too sacred for sexual love.
('77', 60, 1, 15, 115029) And so every woman at once became sister or daughter to me.
('77', 60, 1, 16, 115089) I had enough women about me at Phoenix.
('77', 60, 1, 17, 115129) Several of them were my own relations whom I had enticed to South Africa.
('77', 60, 1, 18, 115203) Others were co workers’ wives or relatives.
('77', 60, 1, 19, 115247) Among these were the Wests and other Englishmen.
('77', 60, 1, 20, 115296) The Wests included West, his sister, his wife, and his mother in law who had become the Granny of the little settlement.
('77', 60, 1, 21, 115417) As has been my wont, I could not keep the new good thing to myself.
('77', 60, 1, 22, 115485) So I presented brahmacharya for the acceptance of all the settlers.
('77', 60, 1, 23, 115553) All approved of it.
('77', 60, 1, 24, 115573) And some took it up and remained true to the ideal.
('77', 60, 1, 25, 115625) My brahmacharya knew nothing of the orthodox laws governing its observance.
('77', 60, 1, 26, 115701) I framed my own rules as occasion necessitated.
('77', 60, 1, 27, 115749) But I have never believed that all contact with women was to be shunned for the due observance of brahmacharya.
('77', 60, 1, 28, 115861) That restraint which demands abstention from all contact, no matter how innocent, with the opposite sex is a forced growth, having little or no vital value.
('77', 60, 1, 29, 116018) Therefore natural contacts for service were never restrained.
('77', 60, 1, 30, 116080) And I found myself enjoying the confidence of many sisters, European and Indian, in South Africa.
('77', 60, 1, 31, 116178) And when I invited the Indian sisters in South Africa to join the civil resistance movement, I found myself one of them.
('77', 60, 1, 32, 116299) I discovered that I was specially fitted to serve womankind.
('77', 60, 1, 33, 116360) To cut the (for me enthralling) story short, my return to India found me in no time one with India’s women.
('77', 60, 1, 34, 116468) The easy access I had to their hearts was an agreeable revelation to me.
('77', 60, 1, 35, 116541) Muslim sisters never kept
('77', 61, 0, 1, 116567) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('77', 61, 1, 2, 116608) purdah before me here even as they did not in South Africa.
('77', 61, 1, 3, 116668) I sleep in the Ashram surrounded by women for they feel safe with me in every respect.
('77', 61, 1, 4, 116755) It should be remembered that there is no privacy in the Segaon Ashram.
('77', 61, 1, 5, 116826) If I were sexually attracted towards women, I have courage enough, even at this time of life, to become a polygamist.
('77', 61, 1, 6, 116944) I do not believe in free love—secret or open.
('77', 61, 1, 7, 116990) Free, open love I have looked upon as dog’s love.
('77', 61, 1, 8, 117040) Secret love is besides cowardly.
('77', 61, 1, 9, 117073) Sanatanist Hindus may abhor my non viloence.
('77', 61, 1, 10, 117118) I know many of them think that Hindus will become cowards if they remain under my influence.
('77', 61, 1, 11, 117211) I know of no man having become a coward under my influence.
('77', 61, 1, 12, 117271) They may decry my non violence as much as they like.
('77', 61, 1, 13, 117324) But they ill serve themselves or Hinduism by indulging in palpable lies.
('77', 61, 1, 14, 117397) SEGAON, October 30, 1939 Harijan, 4 11 1939
('77', 61, 2, 15, 117441) 74. THE NEXT STEP
('77', 61, 3, 16, 117459) I have never felt the weight of responsibility as heavily as I do today in connection with the present impasse with the British Government.
('77', 61, 3, 17, 117599) The resignation of Congress Ministries was a necessity.
('77', 61, 3, 18, 117655) But the next step is by no means clear.
('77', 61, 3, 19, 117695) Congressmen seem to be expecting a big move.
('77', 61, 3, 20, 117740) Some correspondents tell me, if I only give the call, there will be an India wide response such as has never been made before.
('77', 61, 3, 21, 117867) And they assure me that the people will remain non violent.
('77', 61, 3, 22, 117927) Beyond their assurance I have no other proof in support of their statement.
('77', 61, 3, 23, 118003) I have proof in my own possession to the contrary.
('77', 61, 3, 24, 118054) These columns have contained some of that proof.
('77', 61, 3, 25, 118103) I cannot identify myself with any civil disobedience unless I am convinced that Congressmen believe in non violence with all its implications and will follow implicitly the instructions issued from time to time.
('77', 61, 3, 26, 118315) Apart from the uncertainty of the observance of non violence in Congress ranks is the tremendous fact that the Muslim League look upon the Congress as the enemy of the Muslims.
('77', 61, 3, 27, 118492) This makes it well nigh impossible for the Congress to organize successful non violent revolu tion through civil disobedience.
('77', 61, 3, 28, 118619) It will certainly mean Hindu Muslim riots.
('77', 61, 3, 29, 118662) Non violent technique, therefore, demands the reduction of civil disobedience to the lowest term consistent with national self respect.
('77', 61, 3, 30, 118798) The offensive will have to be taken by the British
('77', 62, 0, 1, 118849) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 63
('77', 62, 1, 2, 118897) Government.
('77', 62, 1, 3, 118909) In a situation so delicate and unexampled, no individual Congressman or even Congress Committee can be allowed to take law into their own hands.
('77', 62, 1, 4, 119054) The Working Committee should alone have the right to declare and regulate civil disobedience.
('77', 62, 1, 5, 119148) I have undertaken to guide the Working Committee, but my limitations appal me.
('77', 62, 1, 6, 119227) My physical condition makes it impossible for me to move about as I used to before.
('77', 62, 1, 7, 119311) I am therefore cut off from all outward contact with the masses.
('77', 62, 1, 8, 119376) Even the present Congress workers I do not know personally.
('77', 62, 1, 9, 119436) I never meet them.
('77', 62, 1, 10, 119455) My correspondence has to be restricted as much as possible.
('77', 62, 1, 11, 119515) Therefore, unless Congressmen almost instinctively perceive the duty and the necessity of the preliminary inaction I am prescribing, my guidance will be not only useless but it will be harmful.
('77', 62, 1, 12, 119709) It will create confusion.
('77', 62, 1, 13, 119735) I hold the opinion strongly that whilst by their own action the British Government have made it impossible for the Congress to co operate with them in the prosecution of the war, the Congress must not embarrass them in its prosecution.
('77', 62, 1, 14, 119971) I do not desire anarchy in the country.
('77', 62, 1, 15, 120011) Independence will never come through it.
('77', 62, 1, 16, 120052) I do not wish for the defeat of the British or, for that matter, of the Germans.
('77', 62, 1, 17, 120133) The peoples of Europe have been helplessly drawn into the war.
('77', 62, 1, 18, 120196) But they will soon be awakened from their torpor.
('77', 62, 1, 19, 120246) This war will not be a war to the finish unless the whole of modern civilization is to perish.
('77', 62, 1, 20, 120341) Be that as it may, holding the views I do, I am in no hurry to precipitate civil disobedience.
('77', 62, 1, 21, 120436) My prescription to Congressmen, for the time being, is to consolidate the organization by purging it of all weaknesses.
('77', 62, 1, 22, 120556) I swear by the old constructive programme of communal unity, removal of untouchability and the charkha.
('77', 62, 1, 23, 120660) It is quite clear that non violence is impossible without the first two.
('77', 62, 1, 24, 120733) If India’s villages are to live and prosper, the charkha must become universal.
('77', 62, 1, 25, 120813) Rural civilization is impossible without the charkha and all it implies, i.
('77', 62, 1, 26, 120889) e., revival of village crafts.
('77', 62, 1, 27, 120920) Thus the charkha is the symbol par excellence of non violence.
('77', 62, 1, 28, 120983) And it can occupy the whole of the time of all Congressmen.
('77', 62, 1, 29, 121043) If it makes no appeal to them, either they have no non violence in them or I do not know the A. B. C. of non violence.
('77', 62, 1, 30, 121162) If my love of the charkha is a weakness in me, it is so radical as to make me unfit as a general.
('77', 62, 1, 31, 121260) The wheel is bound up with my scheme of swaraj, indeed with life itself.
('77', 62, 1, 32, 121333) All India should know my credentials on the eve of what can become the last and decisive battle for swaraj.
('77', 62, 1, 33, 121441) SEGAON, October 30, 1939 Harijan, 4 11 1939
('77', 63, 0, 1, 121485) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('77', 63, 1, 2, 121526) 75. GOOD AND BAD
('77', 63, 2, 3, 121543) The more I ponder over Sir Samuel Hoare’s recent speech 1 in the House of Commons the more puzzled I become.
('77', 63, 2, 4, 121652) It is both good and bad.
('77', 63, 2, 5, 121677) But the bad part is so bad that it vitiates the good.
('77', 63, 2, 6, 121731) His statement that the British Govenment have shed imperialism hardly squares with his defence of the promises made to the minorities.
('77', 63, 2, 7, 121866) He gives up the whole of his case when he brackets the Europeans of India and the Princes with the other minorities.
('77', 63, 2, 8, 121983) If Europeans who have made no home in India and whose roots are all in Europe are a minority requiring protection, the British soldiers and civilians too who are a hopeless minority require to be protected.
('77', 63, 2, 9, 122190) In other words, rights acquired by conquest are to remain intact.
('77', 63, 2, 10, 122256) European interests are an imposition protected by the British bayonet.
('77', 63, 2, 11, 122327) A free India will claim to examine every European interest on its merit, and that which conflicts with the national interest will go by the board.
('77', 63, 2, 12, 122474) I turn up The Concise Oxford Dictionary and I find the following definition of imperialism: “Extension of British Empire where trade required protection of the flag.” If this is imperialism, does not Sir Samuel’s speech fully protect it?
('77', 63, 2, 13, 122712) India’s ambition is to destroy that imperialism.
('77', 63, 2, 14, 122761) Do not Princes stand much on the same footing as the Europeans?
('77', 63, 2, 15, 122825) Many, if not most, of them are an imperial creation and sustained for imperial interests.
('77', 63, 2, 16, 122915) The Princes in no way represent their people.
('77', 63, 2, 17, 122961) If I published the complaints I receive weekly from the people of the States, I should need to double the size of Harijan.
('77', 63, 2, 18, 123084) They make a woeful tale neither creditable to the Princes nor to their protector, the British authority.
('77', 63, 2, 19, 123189) Does not this British protectorate mean naked imperialism?
('77', 63, 2, 20, 123248) The Congress is invited to regard the Princes as a minority.
('77', 63, 2, 21, 123309) British power is the overlord without whom the Princes cannot breathe!
('77', 63, 2, 22, 123380) They are not free even to see Congressmen, much less to enter into any settlement with them.
('77', 63, 2, 23, 123473) I do not complain against the Princes for what they are doing in the crisis.
('77', 63, 2, 24, 123550) They are powerless to do otherwise.
('77', 63, 2, 25, 123586) Sir Samuel talks of the Communal Award 2 as a meritorious act of the British Government.
('77', 63, 2, 26, 123675) I am sorry he mentioned it.
('77', 63, 2, 27, 123703) I have very bitter memories of the Award which was being hatched during the
('77', 63, 3, 28, 123779) 1 Vide Appendix “Sir Samuel Hoare’s Speech”, 26 10 1939. 2 Vide 2nd footnote of “Letter to Ramsay Macdonald”, 18 8 1932.
('77', 64, 0, 1, 123900) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 65
('77', 64, 1, 2, 123948) Round Table Conference time.
('77', 64, 1, 3, 123977) I am unable to regard it as a proud British achievement.
('77', 64, 1, 4, 124034) I know how miserably the parties themselves failed.
('77', 64, 1, 5, 124086) I regard the Award as discreditable for all parties.
('77', 64, 1, 6, 124139) I say this apart from its merits which do not bear close scrutiny.
('77', 64, 1, 7, 124206) But the Congress has loyally accepted it because I was party to the request made to the late Mr. MacDonald to arbitrate.
('77', 64, 1, 8, 124327) Then his division of India into Congress India and non Congress India !
('77', 64, 1, 9, 124399) It would have been better if Sir Samuel had talked of armed India and unarmed India.
('77', 64, 1, 10, 124484) The Congress represents the unarmed millions, no matter to what caste or creed they belong.
('77', 64, 1, 11, 124576) Is it right to pit armed India against its unarmed part?
('77', 64, 1, 12, 124633) It will be hard to find a parallel in history in which unarmed people have represented the urge for freedom, turning the very armlessness into the central means for deliverance.
('77', 64, 1, 13, 124811) Sir Samuel has informed the world that India’s battle for freedom cannot be won till unarmed India has come to terms with armed India including, of course, the British Government.
('77', 64, 1, 14, 124991) Again, I do not complain.
('77', 64, 1, 15, 125017) Sir Samuel could not, all of a sudden, alter British tradition and nature.
('77', 64, 1, 16, 125092) Only it is my painful duty to show how an unbiased Indian has understood his speech.
('77', 64, 1, 17, 125177) I have no doubt that Sir Samuel has meant what he has said.
('77', 64, 1, 18, 125237) Only he has said nothing that can quench the parched throats of Congressmen who are thirsting for freedom.
('77', 64, 1, 19, 125344) The Congress has to live up more closely than ever to its creed and develop the non violent strength which will disarm armed India and with it armed Britain.
('77', 64, 1, 20, 125502) If it can do so, it will be the greatest contribution to the peace of the world.
('77', 64, 1, 21, 125583) For peace won’t come out of a clash of arms but out of justice lived and done by unarmed nations in the face of odds.
('77', 64, 2, 22, 125701) SEGAON, October 30, 1939 Harijan, 4 11 1939

('77', 68, 1, 2, 129856) 82. THE CONGRESSMAN
('77', 68, 2, 3, 129876) The Congressman seems to have become a distinct species.
('77', 68, 2, 4, 129933) The various groups who make up the Congress organization have one thing in common.
('77', 68, 2, 5, 130016) They are nationalists to the core.
('77', 68, 2, 6, 130051) They will die for India’s independence as they are living for it.
('77', 68, 2, 7, 130117) They have made nationalism part of their religion, whether they are Hindus, Muslims, Christians or any other.
('77', 68, 2, 8, 130227) Now the Congress contains, besides those who need no other label but that of being Congressmen, socialists, communists, Kisan Sabhaites, trade unionists, Congress nationalists, Royists, ex terrorists, the so called Gandhi ites, etc.
('77', 68, 2, 9, 130460) I have not intentionally omitted any group.
('77', 68, 2, 10, 130504) Some of these have sub divisions.
('77', 68, 2, 11, 130538) The Forward Bloc is an amalgam.
('77', 68, 2, 12, 130570) Its other name is leftists.
('77', 68, 2, 13, 130598) As the Congress movement spreads, it may throw up other groups.
('77', 68, 2, 14, 130662) But all of them have one thing in common: a burning passion for freedom and readiness to die for it.
('77', 68, 2, 15, 130763) It is true that the vast majority of Congressmen are Hindus.
('77', 68, 2, 16, 130824) But they stand apart from other Hindus as we have found in the South during the campaign for temple entry.
('77', 68, 2, 17, 130931) The sanatanists, who I think and hope are a handful have fought the reformers who are mostly Congressmen, and have denounced the latter as traitors to their religion.
('77', 68, 2, 18, 131098) The Hindu Mahasabha is becoming a protest against the Congress.
('77', 68, 2, 19, 131162) Some of its members use about the Congress language calculated to create contempt for it.
('77', 68, 2, 20, 131252) They regard Hindus who belong to the Congress as enemies of Hinduism.
('77', 68, 2, 21, 131322) The Muslims who belong to the Congress are almost outcastes.
('77', 68, 2, 22, 131383) That the Congressman stands for complete independence, for bold social reform, for broad tolerance, has a brilliant record for suffering and sacrifice, is a matter for legitimate satisfaction.
('77', 68, 2, 23, 131576) The formation of different groups in a mass organization like the Congress is inevitable and may be a distinct sign of progress and life.
('77', 68, 2, 24, 131714) But if it is so, why are there communal quarrels, why do the Mahasabhaites distrust Congress Hindus, why do not men and women belonging to all faiths flock to the Congress banner, and, last but not least, is it all well with the groups themselves which I have mentioned?
('77', 68, 2, 25, 131985) Let us examine their condition.
('77', 68, 2, 26, 132017) Are they centripetal or centrifugal?
('77', 68, 2, 27, 132054) Do they strengthen the organization or do they weaken it?
('77', 68, 2, 28, 132112) Are they not bidding for power?
('77', 68, 2, 29, 132144) Do they not distrust one another?
('77', 69, 0, 1, 132178) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('77', 69, 1, 2, 132219) Do they submit to discipline?
('77', 69, 1, 3, 132249) I am not able to give a flattering answer to all these questions.
('77', 69, 1, 4, 132315) I am afraid that these groups contain in themselves the seeds of the decay of the Congress.
('77', 69, 1, 5, 132407) The cause that accounts for weakness within Congress ranks is also the cause that accounts for the Congress failure to draw all communities to its ranks.
('77', 69, 1, 6, 132561) That cause is absence of a living faith in non violence in thought, word and deed.
('77', 69, 1, 7, 132644) Now, therefore, is the time for every one of us to test the efficacy or otherwise of non violence.
('77', 69, 1, 8, 132743) A false step by the Congress at this stage of its career is bound to retard the country’s progress towards its goal.
('77', 69, 1, 9, 132860) Strange as it may appear to Congressmen, I make bold to suggest that the one way to disarm communal suspicion is not to offer civil disobedience in terms of swaraj.
('77', 69, 1, 10, 133025) The prospect that is about to face the country is that of the British Government in alliance with the so called minorities arrayed against the Congress single handed.
('77', 69, 1, 11, 133192) Civil disobedience against this combination is a contradiction in terms.
('77', 69, 1, 12, 133265) It would not even be civil war.
('77', 69, 1, 13, 133297) It would be criminal war.
('77', 69, 1, 14, 133323) If Congressmen, whether labelled or unlabelled, do not subscribe to non violence as I have been developing it in these columns, and do not appreciate the instructions issued by Rajendra Babu and the advice I have tendered 1 in Harijan, they should signify in writing their discontent to Rajendra Babu and tell him what they would like him to do and, if he cannot comply with their wishes, what they would themselves do.
('77', 69, 1, 15, 133743) It must be clear to every Congressman that this is no time for divided counsels, indecision, or half hearted obedience to instructions.
('77', 69, 1, 16, 133879) For decisive action the whole Congress has to move forward in confidence and with one mind.
('77', 69, 2, 17, 133971) ON THE TRAIN TO DELHI, October 31, 1939
('77', 69, 3, 18, 134011) Harijan, 11 11 1939
('77', 69, 4, 19, 134031) 1 Vide “Notes”, 17 10 1939 and “The Next Step”, 30 10 1939.

('77', 73, 1, 2, 137757) 92. SPEECH AT HARIJAN NIVAS, NEW DELHI
('77', 73, 2, 3, 137796) November 2, 1939 The hall built by the Chandiwala brothers in commemoration of Shrimati Janaki Devi 1 has in fact been already open for prayers for the last so many days.
('77', 73, 2, 4, 137967) But this formal function has been organized with the pious feeling that it would be better if I threw open the temple.
('77', 73, 2, 5, 138086) I do not know whether or no my hands would add to its religious merit.
('77', 73, 2, 6, 138157) The importance of this shrine will increase if the hearts of the Harijan children present here are filled with true prayer.
('77', 73, 2, 7, 138281) I would like to say a few words to the Harijan boys who come here for prayer and to their Superintendent Viyogi Hariji.
('77', 73, 2, 8, 138401) Deprivation of food does not do much harm to a man.
('77', 73, 2, 9, 138453) On the other hand it may benefit him, because we often indulge in over eating.
('77', 73, 2, 10, 138532) But prayer is the food of the soul without which it is starved to death.
('77', 73, 2, 11, 138605) The more you pray the better it is.
('77', 73, 2, 12, 138641) In prayer there can be no excess.
('77', 73, 2, 13, 138675) I have never come across a person harmed by excessive prayer.
('77', 73, 2, 14, 138737) We should devote the maximum time to prayer so that ultimately our life becomes one continuous prayer.
('77', 73, 2, 15, 138840) Therefore, if this hall increases such religious faith, the devotion of the brothers who have built it will have borne fruit and the spirit of Shrimati Janaki Devi will rest in peace.
('77', 73, 2, 16, 139024) There are a few Harijan ashrams in the country through which caste Hindus are atoning for their past sins.
('77', 73, 2, 17, 139131) If untouchability is eradicated by such atonement, it will help the preservation of Hinduism.
('77', 73, 2, 18, 139225) Harijan children here are living without any discrimination.
('77', 73, 2, 19, 139286) The superintendent also lives and mixes with them freely without any inhibition.
('77', 73, 2, 20, 139367) It is certainly desirable of them if all pray together in harmony and rhythm.
('77', 73, 2, 21, 139445) But the value of true prayer is never lost for want of any rhythm or harmony.
('77', 73, 2, 22, 139523) Prayer should proceed from the depth of one’s heart.
('77', 73, 2, 23, 139576) If one perseveres, success is assured.
('77', 73, 2, 24, 139615) The very purpose of opening a temple is to strengthen religious feeling.
('77', 73, 2, 25, 139688) If this is fulfilled, the people who have built it will be content.
('77', 73, 2, 26, 139756) May our goodwill bear fruit.
('77', 73, 2, 27, 139785) [From Hindi] Harijan Sevak, 4 11 1939
('77', 73, 3, 28, 139823) 1 Mother of the Chandiwala brothers

('77', 74, 1, 2, 139907) 93. INTERVIEW TO “THE MANCHESTER GUARDIAN”
('77', 74, 2, 3, 139950) NEW DELHI, November 4, 1939
('77', 74, 3, 4, 139978) Mahatma Gandhi, in an interview to the Indian correspondent of The Manchester Guardian on the Lords’ debate 1 on India, said he was shocked at Lord Zetland’s suggestion that the Congress is a Hindu organization; and was amazed that it could emanate from one in the responsible position of the Secretary of State.
('77', 74, 4, 5, 140291) Mahatma Gandhi observed that though the vast majority of Congressmen are Hindus, the Congress contained many Indians of all classes and creeds.
('77', 74, 4, 6, 140435) What is more, from its very commencement the Congress has claimed to be and has been a wholly political organization and never communal.
('77', 74, 4, 7, 140572) It has proved its claim repeatedly and on every relevant occasion.
('77', 74, 4, 8, 140639) The Hindu Mahasabha is a communal organization and it came into being because even notable Hindus thought that the Congress did not and could not protect the special rights of Hindus.
('77', 74, 4, 9, 140823) Lord Zetland as a former Governor and an author knows all these facts.
('77', 74, 4, 10, 140894) His misdescription of the Congress is untimely, disturbing and calculated to increase irritation and bitterness.
('77', 74, 4, 11, 141007) Mahatma Gandhi hopes that Lord Zetland will lose no time to correct what Gandhiji regards as a great blunder.
('77', 74, 4, 12, 141117) The Hindustan Times, 5 11 1939
('77', 74, 5, 13, 141148) 94. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU

('77', 74, 7, 20, 141705) 2 It deals with my position in this connection.

('77', 75, 7, 9, 142513) 96. TRAVANCORE AGAIN
('77', 75, 8, 10, 142534) There was a forced lull in Travancore after the acceptance by the State Congress of my advice to suspend civil disobedience.
('77', 75, 8, 11, 142659) But things seem to have gone from bad to worse.
('77', 75, 8, 12, 142707) The inactivity of the State Congress was perhaps mistaken for fatigue or worse.
('77', 75, 8, 13, 142787) I knew that the State Congress leaders were being held down by me.
('77', 75, 8, 14, 142854) Their loyalty was great.
('77', 75, 8, 15, 142879) But when the other day a deputation came to me and asked me whether, in order to avoid civil disobedience, they were to stop even ordinary activity which one knows as political, I told them that even that severe restraint might be part of the people’s training.
('77', 75, 8, 16, 143141) But I also told them that I could not judge for them in such matters.
('77', 75, 8, 17, 143211) I could not have the data they had.
('77', 75, 8, 18, 143247) They could not help me in judging the atmosphere in Travancore.
('77', 75, 8, 19, 143311) Physical presence there was necessary to enable me to judge.
('77', 75, 8, 20, 143372) No second hand evidence could be of much assistance, at least not to me.
('77', 75, 8, 21, 143445) I told them, therefore, that they must judge for themselves, irrespective of my opinion.
('77', 75, 8, 22, 143534) For I was not prepared to take the risk of curbing even harmless political activity for fear of imaginary consequences.
('77', 75, 8, 23, 143654) The leaders should, therefore,
('77', 75, 9, 24, 143685) 1 Gandhiji passed through Nagpur en route to Wardha.
('77', 76, 0, 1, 143738) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 77
('77', 76, 1, 2, 143786) consider themselves free from any restraint from me.
('77', 76, 1, 3, 143839) After the greatest deliberation they took two steps embodied in restrained language.
('77', 76, 1, 4, 143924) Their resolutions and the Press note in reply are printed below.
('77', 76, 2, 5, 143989) In my opinion the State Congress had every right to dissociate themselves from the glorification of the Dewan’s administration.
('77', 76, 2, 6, 144117) Even an adversary is entitled to many happy returns of the day.
('77', 76, 2, 7, 144181) But it is another matter when an attempt is made, as it is said to have been made in the present case, to make political capital out of an innocent event like a birthday.
('77', 76, 2, 8, 144352) The first resolution is a protest against such political use of the Dewan’s birthday.
('77', 76, 2, 9, 144438) The second resolution has nothing controversial about it.
('77', 76, 2, 10, 144496) It is a mere assertion of the right to hold public meetings, etc.
('77', 76, 2, 11, 144562) News has now been received that Shri Thanu Pillai, Shri Philipose and three others were arrested on the 2nd instant and that the State Congress office was taken possession of by the Travancore Government.
('77', 76, 2, 12, 144767) Furniture, it is said, was thrown out.

('77', 76, 2, 18, 145256) I have no doubt that it is the surest way to swaraj if those who are imprisoned possess pure hearts.

('77', 78, 1, 2, 147045) 99. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('77', 78, 2, 3, 147074) SEGAON, November 6, 1939 The London Times editorial seems to me to be unfair.
('77', 78, 2, 4, 147152) The minorities question has invariably been brought up whenever the question of India’s freedom has come to the fore.
('77', 78, 2, 5, 147270) To represent the Congress and its demand as totalitarian is to misrepresent facts.
('77', 78, 2, 6, 147353) This misrepresentation is not less serious because it is unconscious.
('77', 78, 2, 7, 147423) The Congress has deliberately discarded the use of force.
('77', 78, 2, 8, 147481) It has no military backing or tradition.
('77', 78, 2, 9, 147522) It has from its inception believed in communal unity.
('77', 78, 2, 10, 147576) It seeks to represent non Hindus as well as Hindus.
('77', 78, 2, 11, 147628) It has had Parsis, Muslims and Christians leading it.
('77', 78, 2, 12, 147682) It has gone out of its way to placate all communities.
('77', 78, 2, 13, 147737) It could not do otherwise as its only sanction was constitutional agitation till it forged non co operation and civil disobedience as an addition to constitutional agitation and as an effective substitute for violence.
('77', 78, 2, 14, 147956) Communal differences have been used by the British Government to thwart India’s aspiration.
('77', 78, 2, 15, 148048) That the process is likely to have been unconscious does not make it less mischievous.
('77', 78, 2, 16, 148135) That the Congress has no desire for loaves and fishes must be crystal clear from wholesale resignations of Congress Ministries.
('77', 78, 2, 17, 148263) The Congress will never be party to communal quarrels.
('77', 78, 2, 18, 148318) It will rather stand aside and wander in the wilderness and wait for a better day.
('77', 78, 2, 19, 148401) Even now the ugly spectacle of playing off the league against the Congress seems to be going on.
('77', 78, 2, 20, 148498) I had expected that the stupendous European crisis would bring better perception to British statesmen.
('77', 78, 2, 21, 148601) The mention of the Princes in this connection is particularly unfair.
('77', 78, 2, 22, 148671) They owe their existence to the Paramount Power and have no status independent of it.
('77', 78, 2, 23, 148757) Strange as the assertion may appear, they can do nothing good or big without the consent, tacit or implied, of the Paramount Power.
('77', 78, 2, 24, 148889) They represent nobody but themselves.
('77', 78, 2, 25, 148927) To invite the Congress to settle with the Princes is the same as inviting it to settle with the Paramount Power.
('77', 78, 2, 26, 149040) The Times wants the Congress record of dealings with Muslims
('77', 78, 3, 27, 149101) 1 This appeared under the title “Unfair”.
('77', 78, 3, 28, 149143) The statement was also published in The Hindu, 7 11 1939.
('77', 79, 0, 1, 149201) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('77', 79, 1, 2, 149242) and Depressed Classes during the last two years.
('77', 79, 1, 3, 149291) All that I can say is, ‘Let Governors of Provinces speak.’ That the Muslim League and some Depressed Class leaders complain is nothing strange.
('77', 79, 1, 4, 149435) Some discontent is inevitable in democracy.
('77', 79, 1, 5, 149479) The Congress has made a handsome and sporting offer.
('77', 79, 1, 6, 149532) Let a Constituent Assembly of elected representatives frame a constitution for future Government of India subject to safe guards for protection of rights of minorities to their satisfaction.

('77', 79, 2, 8, 149761) Harijan, 11 11 1939
('77', 79, 3, 9, 149781) 100. OPINIONS DIFFER
('77', 79, 4, 10, 149802) An M. A. of Aligarh writes :
('77', 79, 5, 11, 149831) You have said on many occasions that your study of the holy Koran has revealed to you that Islam enjoins non violence upon its followers.
('77', 79, 5, 12, 149969) You again say that your study of the life of the holy prophet confirms you in this belief.
('77', 79, 5, 13, 150060) Allow me to say that it must be only a sort of ‘wishful’ reading that you have done.
('77', 79, 5, 14, 150145) The simple fact is that your philosophy of ahimsa eschews the use of force altogether.
('77', 79, 5, 15, 150232) Islam, on the contrary, does allow the use of force on certain occasions.
('77', 79, 5, 16, 150306) Did not the Prophet meet force with force at Badr?
('77', 79, 5, 17, 150357) I dare not cite any authority because you have refused to accept any interpretation except your own.
('77', 79, 5, 18, 150458) Yet I hope you will show some respect to what your own hypnotized Maulana Saheb said so long ago as during the first non co operation movement.
('77', 79, 5, 19, 150602) He said in his statement to the court: “I do not agree with Mahatma Gandhi that the use of force should not be allowed in any case.
('77', 79, 5, 20, 150734) Because I am a Muslim I believe that the use of force is allowed on the particular occasions specified by Islam.” Again he said in the same statement to the court during his trial: “Against the non Muslim Government, Islam prescribes only sword, protracted battle and the cutting of throats.” I am sure Maulana Saheb cannot deny it even today.
('77', 79, 6, 21, 151078) So much for non violence in Islam.
('77', 79, 6, 22, 151113) As to the question whether the Muslims are a separate nation or not, I would say that the Muslims have been a separate nation ever since the beginning of Islam.
('77', 79, 6, 23, 151274) They were so when Mohammed Bin Kasim first set foot on Indian soil, they were so during the days of the Moghul Empire, they are so even today, and they will remain the same for ever if they are true to their religion.
('77', 79, 6, 24, 151492) Akbar attempted to evolve not only a common religion but also a common social system, but were not his
('77', 79, 7, 25, 151595) 1 Vide also “Interview to The Manchester Guardian”, 4 11 1939.
('77', 80, 0, 1, 151658) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 81
('77', 80, 1, 2, 151706) attempts doomed to failure?
('77', 80, 1, 3, 151734) The Muslims are a separate nation in the sense that they cannot merge their identity with any other community.
('77', 80, 1, 4, 151845) But this need not frighten the champions of unity at all.
('77', 80, 1, 5, 151903) Co operation in some particular sphere for some particular goal is always possible.
('77', 80, 1, 6, 151987) Breathing the same air and inhabiting the same land does not make a nation.
('77', 80, 1, 7, 152063) It is the unity of thought that really matters.
('77', 80, 1, 8, 152111) It is religion which moulds the mind.
('77', 80, 1, 9, 152149) A Muslim may be the next door neighbour of Sikh.
('77', 80, 1, 10, 152198) But their viewpoints, their modes of thought and their modes of life will always differ from each other.
('77', 80, 1, 11, 152303) The air is the same all round the globe.
('77', 80, 1, 12, 152344) Is the air of England in any way different from that of India?
('77', 80, 1, 13, 152407) Physical surroundings affect only the physical features.
('77', 80, 1, 14, 152464) The mind is not affected by them.
('77', 80, 1, 15, 152498) Of course, the Christians are also a separate nation, and so are the Parsis.
('77', 80, 1, 16, 152575) India is a land of nationalities.
('77', 80, 1, 17, 152609) It will be a red letter day in the history of India when the Indian National Congress is transformed into a ‘Federation of Indian Nations’.
('77', 80, 2, 18, 152749) Yes, the Muslims are a separate nation in China.
('77', 80, 2, 19, 152798) If the insinuation is that they merged themselves with the other Chinese, then I can only say that they stand as an object lesson before the whole Islamic world.
('77', 80, 2, 20, 152960) Islamic brotherhood will be reduced to a mere farce if the same process continues.
('77', 80, 2, 21, 153043) Islam has definitely laid down that the Muslims should have some distinction even in their dress.
('77', 80, 2, 22, 153141) Does not Maulana Saheb stand prominent among the members of the Congress Working Committee ?
('77', 80, 2, 23, 153234) I have no doubt that this letter represents the present mood of many educated Muslims.
('77', 80, 2, 24, 153321) I do not propose to enter into any long argument about the interpretation of the Koran.
('77', 80, 2, 25, 153409) Being a non Muslim I am at a disadvantage.
('77', 80, 2, 26, 153452) If I began an argument, the natural retort would be: ‘How can you, a non Muslim, interpret Muslim scriptures ?’ It would serve no purpose to answer back that I have the same reverence for Islam and the other faiths as I have for my own.
('77', 80, 2, 27, 153689) I may, however, inform my correspondent that I had before my mind the battle of Badr and similar incidents in the Prophet’s life.
('77', 80, 2, 28, 153819) I was aware of verses in the Koran itself contradicting my interpretation.
('77', 80, 2, 29, 153894) I suggest, nevertheless, that it is possible that the teaching of a book or a man’s life may be different from isolated texts in a book or incidents in a life, however many the latter may be.
('77', 80, 2, 30, 154086) The Mahabharata is the story of a bloody war.
('77', 80, 2, 31, 154132) But I have maintained in the teeth of orthodox Hindu opposition that it is a book written to establish the futility of war and violence.
('77', 80, 2, 32, 154269) I have no right to speak for the Maulana Saheb.
('77', 80, 2, 33, 154317) He is well able to take care of himself.
('77', 80, 2, 34, 154358) I must confess that I have no recollection of
('77', 81, 0, 1, 154404) 82 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('77', 81, 1, 2, 154445) the Maulana Saheb having given the evidence quoted.
('77', 81, 1, 3, 154497) I do not question the veracity of my correspondent.
('77', 81, 1, 4, 154549) Only that evidence does not affect the opinion I have held for many years about the central teaching of the holy Koran.
('77', 81, 1, 5, 154669) Opinions will differ to the end of time.
('77', 81, 1, 6, 154710) I plead for mutual forbearance.
('77', 81, 1, 7, 154742) The proposition laid down by my correspondent about nations is startling.
('77', 81, 1, 8, 154816) There may be arguable grounds for maintaining that Muslims in India are a separate nation.
('77', 81, 1, 9, 154907) But I have never heard it said that there are as many nations as there are religions on earth.
('77', 81, 1, 10, 155002) If there are, it would follow that a man changes his nationality when he changes his faith.
('77', 81, 1, 11, 155094) According to my correspondent, the English, Egyptians, Americans, Japanese, etc., are not nations, but Muslims, Parsis, Sikhs, Hindus, Christians, Jews, Buddhists are different nations no matter where born.
('77', 81, 1, 12, 155301) I am afraid my correspondent occupies very weak ground in maintaining that nations are or should be divided according to their religions.
('77', 81, 1, 13, 155439) In his zeal to maintain an untenable proposition he has overproved his case.
('77', 81, 1, 14, 155516) I must deny that the Muslim dynasties divided India into two nations.
('77', 81, 1, 15, 155586) Akbar’s example is irrelevant.
('77', 81, 1, 16, 155617) He aimed at a fusion of religions.
('77', 81, 1, 17, 155652) It was a dream not to be realized.
('77', 81, 1, 18, 155687) But the other Muslim emperors and kings surely regarded India as one indivisible whole.
('77', 81, 1, 19, 155775) That is how I learnt history as a boy.
('77', 81, 1, 20, 155814) If we Hindus, Muslims and others are to evolve democracy, we shall do so only by the whole nation speaking its mind through its representatives elected under the broadest franchise possible, and that either through British goodwill or in the teeth of its opposition.
('77', 81, 1, 21, 156081) The pronouncements made on behalf of the British Government give no promise of British goodwill.
('77', 81, 1, 22, 156178) British imperialism is still vigorous and, in spite of Sir Samuel Hoare’s declaration 1 to the contrary, it will die hard.
('77', 81, 1, 23, 156301) The proposal to vivisect India is a contribution to imperialistic growth.
('77', 81, 1, 24, 156375) For vivisection can only be made by the aid of the British bayonet or through a deadly civil war.
('77', 81, 1, 25, 156473) I hope the Congress will be party to neither game.
('77', 81, 1, 26, 156524) British refusal to make the required declaration of Britain’s war aims about India has perhaps come as blessing in disguise.
('77', 81, 1, 27, 156649) It removes the Congress out of the way to enable the Muslim League to make its choice, unfettered by the Congress administration in eight Provinces 2, as to whether it will keep the British yoke by
('77', 81, 2, 28, 156847) 1 Vide Appendix “Sir Samuel Hoare’s Speech”, 26 10 1939. 2 Assam, Bihar, Bombay, Central Provinces, Madras, Orissa, United Provinces and the North West Frontier Province.

('77', 83, 1, 2, 158524) 103. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('77', 83, 2, 3, 158554) SEGAON, November 8, 1939 I have read with respectful attention His Excellency the Viceroy’s broadcast 2 and his introductory remarks 3 on the correspondence between himself and Shri Rajendra Prasad and Jinnah Saheb released by His Excellency.
('77', 83, 2, 4, 158797) I welcome His Excellency’s refusal to accept defeat and his determination to solve what seems to have become insoluble.
('77', 83, 2, 5, 158917) I share to the fullest extent His Excellency’s anxiety to reach a solution.
('77', 83, 2, 6, 158993) Without, therefore, waiting for the Congress reaction to these two declarations and purely for the sake of assisting the common cause, I would like to suggest that no solution is possible unless an acceptable declaration of war aims about India is forthcoming.
('77', 83, 2, 7, 159254) The pronouncements hitherto made, whether, here or in Great Britain, are after the old style, suspected and discredited by freedom loving India.
('77', 83, 2, 8, 159399) If imperialism is dead, there must be a clear break with the past.
('77', 83, 2, 9, 159466) Language suited to the new era has to be used.
('77', 83, 2, 10, 159513) If the time has not yet come for the acceptance of this fundamental truth, I would urge that further effort at reaching a solution should be suspended.
('77', 83, 2, 11, 159665) In this connection I would remind British statesmen that what is wanted is a declaration of Britain’s intention regarding her Indian policy irrespective of India’s wishes.
('77', 83, 2, 12, 159837) A slave holder, who has decided to abolish slavery, does not consult his slaves whether they desire freedom or not.
('77', 83, 2, 13, 159953) Once a declaration to free India from bondage, not in stages but at once, is made, an interim solution will be found to be easy.
('77', 83, 2, 14, 160082) Protection of rights of minorities will then become simple.
('77', 83, 2, 15, 160142) The game of seesaw will cease.
('77', 83, 2, 16, 160173) The minorities are entitled to protection, not in stages but to the fullest extent and in one single step.
('77', 83, 2, 17, 160280) No charter of freedom will be worth looking at which does not ensure the same measure of freedom for the minorities as for the majority.
('77', 83, 2, 18, 160417) The minorities will be full fledged partners in the framing of the
('77', 83, 3, 19, 160484) 1 This appeared under the title “End the Game of Seesaw”.
('77', 83, 3, 20, 160542) The Statement was also published in The Hindu, 9 11 1939. 2 Vide Appendix “Viceroy’s Broadcast Declaration”, 5 11 1939. 3 Vide Appendix “Viceroy’s Prefatory Remarks on Correspondence with Leaders”, 5 11 1939.
('77', 84, 0, 1, 160751) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 85
('77', 84, 1, 2, 160799) constitution.
('77', 84, 1, 3, 160813) How that can be attained will depend upon the wisdom of the representatives charged with the sacred duty of preparing the constitution.
('77', 84, 1, 4, 160949) Britain has hitherto held power—this is inevitable in any system of imperialism—by playing the minorities against the so called majority and has thus made an agreed solution among the component parts well nigh impossible.
('77', 84, 1, 5, 161171) The burden of finding a formula for the protection of minorities should be thrown on the parties themselves.
('77', 84, 1, 6, 161280) So long as Britain considers it her mission to bear this burden, so long will she continue to feel the necessity of holding India as a dependency.
('77', 84, 1, 7, 161427) And patriots impatient for deliverance will fight, non violently if I can guide them and violently if I fail and perish in the attempt.
('77', 84, 1, 8, 161563) God’s curse of war, I had hoped and still hope, would be turned into a blessing by Britain realizing that the one thing needful for her to justify and hasten the end of this war was to free a great and ancient country like India from her yoke.
('77', 84, 1, 9, 161807) Believing as I do in the Viceroy’s sincerity, I would urge fellow workers not to lose patience.
('77', 84, 1, 10, 161903) There can be no civil resistance so long as, first, the Viceroy is exploring the possibilities of a settlement, secondly, the Muslim League blocks the way, and thirdly, there is indiscipline and disunity in Congress ranks.

('77', 84, 1, 13, 162310) No Congressman can be party to it.
('77', 84, 1, 14, 162345) I observe that my note 1 in Harijan has shocked Jinnah Saheb.
('77', 84, 1, 15, 162407) I am sorry for it.
('77', 84, 1, 16, 162426) But at this sgage I would not defend myself.
('77', 84, 1, 17, 162471) I do not want to mar in any way the negotiations between him and Pandit Nehru which I hope will be resumed soon and pray will lead to communal peace.
('77', 84, 1, 18, 162621) Since making the above statement I have read the report of the further statement 2 of the Secretary of State in the House of Lords yesterday.
('77', 84, 1, 19, 162763) It leaves the main position unchanged.

('77', 89, 1, 2, 168197) of the Bombay Corporation.
('77', 89, 1, 3, 168224) Badruddin Tyabji was for years a decisive factor in the deliberations of the Congress.
('77', 89, 1, 4, 168311) Who does not know that whilst Hakim Saheb Ajmal Khan was alive nothing could be done by the Congress if it had not his imprimatur?
('77', 89, 1, 5, 168442) Dr. Ansari was for years Joint General Secretary.
('77', 89, 1, 6, 168492) The readers know the influence that the Ali Brothers exercised over the Congress during the Khilafat days.
('77', 89, 1, 7, 168599) Today the Working Committee does not move without Maulana Abul Kalam Azad’s co operation and wise guidance.
('77', 89, 1, 8, 168707) His is the decisive voice on Hindu Muslim questions.
('77', 89, 1, 9, 168760) Through its whole history now running into the second half of a century the Congress has ever striven to represent the whole of India in a manner no other organization has done.
('77', 89, 1, 10, 168938) Every victory scored by the Congress has benefited all communities.
('77', 89, 1, 11, 169006) “If such is really the case, why has the Congress usurped the function that belongs to the All India Hindu Mahasabha?” ask some angry correspondents.
('77', 89, 1, 12, 169156) The Tribune has also pointed out what has appeared to the Editor the illogicality of the Congress.
('77', 89, 1, 13, 169255) The illogicality has to be admitted.
('77', 89, 1, 14, 169292) But neither life nor institutions are governed by logic.
('77', 89, 1, 15, 169349) Obviously, the Congress felt the necessity of a communal adjustment for the political advancement of the country, and the Congress League Pact of 1916 was born.
('77', 89, 1, 16, 169510) Ever since that time the Congress has made communal unity a plank in the Congress programme.
('77', 89, 1, 17, 169603) Though the function should logically belong to communal organizations, a mass organization like the Congress cannot look on if communities quarrel and when in the national interest a solution becomes necessary.
('77', 89, 1, 18, 169814) Thus the Congress could not shirk what came to it as a clear call to duty.
('77', 89, 1, 19, 169889) The Congress is and should be the organization to take a purely nationalistic and impartial view on communal questions.
('77', 89, 1, 20, 170009) Whatever may be said to the contrary, I maintain that the Congress embodies the hope and aspirations of India.
('77', 89, 1, 21, 170120) It can conclude no pact with any person if it does not represent the whole of India in so far as her political aspirations are concerned.
('77', 89, 1, 22, 170258) Its traditions unfit it to represent Hindus as against Muslims or vice versa.
('77', 89, 1, 23, 170336) It is fit to represent the common interest of all sons of Hindustan.
('77', 89, 1, 24, 170405) I can see nothing wrong in the Congress trying to arrange pacts with men or their organizations for the furtherance of common interest.
('77', 89, 1, 25, 170541) Needless to say they must be all mutually helpful, never contradictory.
('77', 89, 1, 26, 170613) It is a difficult task no doubt.
('77', 89, 1, 27, 170646) But if people and organizations extend their goodwill to the Congress, the task is not beyond its scope or capacity.
('77', 89, 1, 28, 170763) It does not inspire that all round trust
('77', 90, 0, 1, 170804) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 91
('77', 90, 1, 2, 170852) It may therefore have to wait for that day.
('77', 90, 1, 3, 170896) If some other organization does it, Congressmen will welcome it.

('77', 90, 2, 5, 171007) 114. UNNECESSARY ALARM
('77', 90, 3, 6, 171030) Writing on my statement 1 on the Viceregal preface 2 to the correspondence between the Viceroy and Shri Rajendra Prasad and Jinnah Saheb, an esteemed co worker says :
('77', 90, 4, 7, 171197) I have read with some surprise and distress your statement in today’s papers which makes any further action by us dependent on a settlement with the Muslim league and on the Viceroy continuing his efforts at parleying.
('77', 90, 4, 8, 171416) I should imagine that this attitude makes any settlement either with the British Government or the Muslim League most difficult.
('77', 90, 4, 9, 171545) This sentiment is probably shared by many Congressmen.
('77', 90, 4, 10, 171600) I must therefore try to dispel the fear.
('77', 90, 4, 11, 171641) In my opinion suspension of civil disobedience is inherent in both the cases.
('77', 90, 4, 12, 171719) We may not precipitate civil disobedience whilst the Viceroy is making an effort to placate parties.
('77', 90, 4, 13, 171820) The suspension cannot be indefinite or even prolonged.
('77', 90, 4, 14, 171875) We may not put ourselves in the wrong.
('77', 90, 4, 15, 171914) Suspension for the sake of the Viceroy is an aid to settlement.
('77', 90, 4, 16, 171978) As to the Muslim League, it seems to me to be self evident that, whilst we are quarrelling among ourselves, we cannot resort to civil disobedience on any large scale.
('77', 90, 4, 17, 172145) This is obvious.
('77', 90, 4, 18, 172162) Moreover we cannot come to a true settlement by hiding the truth from ourselves or others.
('77', 90, 4, 19, 172253) I refuse to believe that Muslims can possibly hold up for any length of time the progress of the country which is as much theirs as others’.
('77', 90, 4, 20, 172394) I see no harm in making the admission that, if the crores of Muslims do not desire freedom, they can at least for a time prevent it for the others, unless the latter are prepared to fight the former.
('77', 90, 4, 21, 172594) I have eliminated that possibility so far as the Congress is concerned.
('77', 90, 4, 22, 172666) The admission of the obvious is a gesture of goodwill towards the Muslim League.
('77', 90, 4, 23, 172747) It throws also the onus on the League of blocking the country’s progress.
('77', 90, 4, 24, 172821) The admission should improve the prospect of a

('77', 91, 1, 2, 173042) settlement.
('77', 91, 1, 3, 173054) It is worthwhile noticing the use of the word ‘action’ in the remarks quoted by me.
('77', 91, 1, 4, 173138) What I have contemplated is merely suspension of civil disobedience in the event of the two contingencies mentioned by me, not of every variety of action.
('77', 91, 1, 5, 173293) The Congress is not a static organization.
('77', 91, 1, 6, 173336) It is ever moving.
('77', 91, 1, 7, 173355) Whilst I cannot anticipate events, I have no doubt that the Congress will find means other than civil disobedience, within its self imposed limits, of dealing with the crisis.
('77', 91, 1, 8, 173531) I must repeat that we shall harm the cause by being impatient.
('77', 91, 1, 9, 173594) I daily receive letters from men and women telling me that they are ready for the word and they will give a good account of themselves, and that I need have no fear of an outbreak of violence.
('77', 91, 1, 10, 173787) To all these I would say that, if they are sincere in their professions, patient waiting will add to their strength and ensure success.

('77', 91, 7, 19, 174180) 116. POLITICS v.
('77', 91, 8, 20, 174197) In response to my suggestion in my article 1 on the Congressman, Shri M. N. Roy has sent a long letter not to Dr. Rajendra Prasad but to me.
('77', 91, 8, 21, 174338) He asks for a public discussion of the points raised by him.
('77', 91, 8, 22, 174399) Omitting the prefatory paragraphs which have no interest for the reader, the letter is reproduced elsewhere.
('77', 91, 8, 23, 174508) To take the ministerial resignations 2 first, I feel sure that they
('77', 91, 9, 24, 174576) 1 Vide “The Congressman”, 31 10 1939. 2 In his letter, M. N. Roy said that “It was not necessary to have the Congress Ministers resign at this stage.”
('77', 92, 0, 1, 174727) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 93
('77', 92, 1, 2, 174775) have added to the prestige of the Congress.
('77', 92, 1, 3, 174819) The Working Committee would no doubt have done better to have accepted my proposal, only if it could have assimilated non violence with all the implications suggested by me.
('77', 92, 1, 4, 174993) But the members of the Working Committee were too conscious of their duty to accept my proposal mechanically and without heart belief.
('77', 92, 1, 5, 175128) The Working Committee’s resolution was, therefore, the only true course for the Working Committee to adopt.
('77', 92, 1, 6, 175236) Having done so, resignations were the logical result.
('77', 92, 1, 7, 175290) It would have been unbecoming to have retained office for the doubtful advantage of guarding civil liberty.
('77', 92, 1, 8, 175398) If they were ministers of autonomous States they could never have been ignored as they were about the war.
('77', 92, 1, 9, 175505) Having been ignored, they would have been given satisfaction, when the attention of the British Government was drawn by the Working Committee to the grievous omission and when they were told how they could repair the mischief and retain India’s co operation in the prosecution of the war.
('77', 92, 1, 10, 175794) The least that the Ministers could do, therefore, was to resign if only to show the hollowness of autonomy.
('77', 92, 1, 11, 175902) To remain in office after the discovery of their impotence would have been to court ignominy.
('77', 92, 1, 12, 175996) To retain office for the protection of civil liberty would have been to mistake the wood for the tree.
('77', 92, 1, 13, 176099) And Shri Roy may feel quite sure that the weakened Ministers would have been poor guardians of civil liberty.
('77', 92, 1, 14, 176209) The Governors would have set aside their decisions and caught hold of those whom they would have chosen to imprison.
('77', 92, 1, 15, 176326) The Ministers had taken office principally to advance independence.
('77', 92, 1, 16, 176394) When they failed, they were bound to forgo every other advantage however great in itself.
('77', 92, 1, 17, 176484) And they can never go back to their offices so long as the demand of the Congress remains unsatisfied.
('77', 92, 1, 18, 176587) Civil disobedience is by no means the next inevitable forward step.
('77', 92, 1, 19, 176655) It depends upon a variety of circumstances some of which I have already mentioned.
('77', 92, 1, 20, 176738) Inaction is often the most effective action in the strategy of war—more so when the war is non violent.
('77', 92, 1, 21, 176842) Now for the crucial point.
('77', 92, 1, 22, 176869) 1 Non violence is the central fact of the civil disobedience technique.
('77', 92, 1, 23, 176941) It was in 1920 that the Congress hooked its politics deliberately to fundamental morals and vital social reform.
('77', 92, 1, 24, 177054) It came to the conclusion that swaraj could not be won without non violence and certain definite social reform, viz,.
('77', 92, 2, 25, 177172) 1 M. N. Roy criticized the doctrine of non violence as “having no bearing upon the political programme of the Congress”.
('77', 93, 0, 1, 177293) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('77', 93, 1, 2, 177334) prohibition and removal of untouchability.
('77', 93, 1, 3, 177377) It also put the charkha at the centre of its economic programme.
('77', 93, 1, 4, 177442) Indeed it eschewed the then known political programme, i.e., the parliamentary.
('77', 93, 1, 5, 177522) Hence the introduction of morals into Congress politics was not and is not irrelevent to the Congress fight for freedom.
('77', 93, 1, 6, 177643) It is its core.
('77', 93, 1, 7, 177659) There were a few grumblers then.
('77', 93, 1, 8, 177692) But the vast majority welcomed the programme as the Congress had never done in the whole of its brilliant history.
('77', 93, 1, 9, 177807) That programme justified itself by giving rise to a mass awakening on a phenomenal scale.
('77', 93, 1, 10, 177897) By it the Congress gained an importance it had never before enjoyed.
('77', 93, 1, 11, 177966) Shri Roy would not expect me at this stage to repeat here the argument that led to the enthusiastic acceptance of the programme.
('77', 93, 1, 12, 178095) He should turn to the pages of Young India if he would know the pros and cons of the subject.
('77', 93, 1, 13, 178189) The Congress became a mass democratic organization from the time of acceptance of the programme, and it framed a democratic Constitution 1 which stands to this day without much material and fundamental alteration.
('77', 93, 1, 14, 178403) The Congress has a double function.
('77', 93, 1, 15, 178439) It is a democratic organization in peace time.
('77', 93, 1, 16, 178486) It becomes a non violent army in war time.
('77', 93, 1, 17, 178529) In its second capacity it has no voting power.
('77', 93, 1, 18, 178576) Its will is expressed by its general whoever he may be.
('77', 93, 1, 19, 178632) Every unit has to tender him willing obedience in thought, word and deed.
('77', 93, 1, 20, 178706) Yes, even in thought, since the fight is non violent.
('77', 93, 1, 21, 178760) Shri Roy and other Congressmen do not need to be told that I am not in the habit of losing co workers 2. I go a long way with them in winning their affection and retaining it.
('77', 93, 1, 22, 178936) But there does come a limit beyond which my compromise does not and cannot and should not go.
('77', 93, 1, 23, 179030) No compromise is worth the name which endangers chances of success.
('77', 93, 1, 24, 179098) SEGAON, November 14, 1939 Harijan, 18 11 1939

('77', 94, 1, 2, 179543) 117. NOTES
('77', 94, 2, 3, 179554) AWARD OR DECISION?
('77', 94, 2, 4, 179573) Protests against an innocent sentence in my article ‘Good and Bad’ 1 (Harijan, 4 11 1939) are being showered upon me from all sides.
('77', 94, 2, 5, 179706) The writers pay me unintended compliment for accuracy when they detect and severely criticize a hasty inaccuracy in my writings.
('77', 94, 2, 6, 179835) I admit that what I have described as an award was after all not an award but a decision of the British Government.
('77', 94, 2, 7, 179951) And if it was an award, there could be no question of my being party to it.
('77', 94, 2, 8, 180027) But apart from that my “being party” requires an explanation.
('77', 94, 2, 9, 180089) I was signatory to no application to the late Mr. Ramsay MacDonald.
('77', 94, 2, 10, 180157) But having refused to sign the reference that was placed before me, I wrote 2 to the deceased Prime Minister to the effect that whatever all parties agreed to in the matter of communal adjustment would be accepted by the Congress.
('77', 94, 2, 11, 180388) That project, however, fell through and there was no award but a decision given by the British Government in the absence of an agreed reference.
('77', 94, 2, 12, 180533) A lapse of memory on my part cannot alter facts.
('77', 94, 2, 13, 180582) But I am sorry for the trouble so many correspondents have been put to owing to my inaccuracy.
('77', 94, 2, 14, 180677) Beyond however expressing my sorrow, I am afraid I shall not be able to mend my ways.
('77', 94, 2, 15, 180763) Working under double pressure the slip like the one that has angered so many correspondents is likely to recur.
('77', 94, 2, 16, 180875) But would be correspondents will find me always ready to correct inaccuracies whenever they occur.
('77', 94, 2, 17, 180974) And let my critics remember that of the neutral formula 3 of the Congress too, for which they have suddenly developed a liking, I was the author.
('77', 94, 2, 18, 181120) They may also feel assured that if the time came during my lifetime for an agreed revision of the decision, which has many glaring defects, they will find me among the workers helping to evolve an equitable adjustment.
('77', 94, 2, 19, 181339) What I will not do is to make an appeal to the British Government to revise it over the heads of the parties affected.
('77', 94, 2, 20, 181458) It stands till the parties agree to purge it of its absurdities.
('77', 94, 2, 21, 181523) SEGAON, November 14, 1939 Harijan, 18 11 1939
('77', 94, 3, 22, 181569) 1 Vide”Good and Bad”, 30 10 1939; also “Notes”, 27 11 1939, sub title, “Communal Decision Again”.
('77', 94, 3, 23, 181667) 2 Vide “Letter to Prime Minister”, 14 11 1931. 3 Vide “Proposed Communal Solution”, 16 7 1931.

('77', 102, 6, 8, 191411) 132. INTERVIEW TO A CO WORKER 2
('77', 102, 7, 9, 191443) [On or before November 17, 1939]
('77', 102, 8, 10, 191476) CO WORKER: I have come to listen to you, trusting as I do in your leadership.
('77', 102, 9, 11, 191554) GANDHIJI: Mine is an insipid leadership.
('77', 102, 9, 12, 191595) I have nothing but this 3 to show.
('77', 102, 10, 13, 191630) Your statement 4 about civil disobedience is perplexing.
('77', 102, 10, 14, 191687) It does not speak for itself.
('77', 102, 10, 15, 191717) Thus when you say we should not start civil disobedience if the Muslim League blocks the way, I feel very much intrigued.
('77', 102, 10, 16, 191839) Is there fear of communal rioting?
('77', 102, 10, 17, 191874) Why should there be a riot?
('77', 102, 10, 18, 191902) Why was there one the other day in Nellore?
('77', 102, 11, 19, 191946) Oh, that was over some Diwali affair, nothing to do with politics.
('77', 102, 11, 20, 192013) Everything to do with want of communal unity.
('77', 102, 12, 21, 192059) You think they will obstruct us, lest we should secure our demands?
('77', 102, 12, 22, 192127) No, they will say in fighting Government we are fighting them and obstructing them in getting what they want by co operation.
('77', 102, 12, 23, 192253) Do you want to fight the Mussalmans?
('77', 102, 13, 24, 192290) 1 The reference is to a letter dated Bombay, November 10, 1939, from Shankerlal Banker to the addressee, at the back of which Gandhiji had written this letter.
('77', 102, 13, 25, 192450) 2 The interview is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s article “Puzzled and Perplexed”, dated “Segaon, November 17”.
('77', 102, 13, 26, 192562) 3 Mahadev Desai explains: “Gandhiji was laughing and pointing to the spinning wheel which he was trying to put right.” 4 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 8 11 1939 and “Unnecessary Alarm”, 13 11 1939.
('77', 103, 0, 1, 192761) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 104
('77', 103, 1, 2, 192803) In your talks 1 with Jinnah Saheb did you get any such impression from him?
('77', 103, 1, 3, 192879) He gave me no such impression.
('77', 103, 1, 4, 192910) But nothing more than ordinary common sense is required to see what I have said.
('77', 103, 1, 5, 192991) In fact I am surprised that you do not see what is so obvious.
('77', 103, 1, 6, 193054) Others of your party are clear that there would be trouble, but they say that we should not mind it, we should be able to deal with it.
('77', 103, 1, 7, 193190) I say to them it is wrong to anticipate a riot in the hope that we can deal with it.
('77', 103, 1, 8, 193275) If a big minority is opposed to the launching of civil disobedience, I should say let us wait.
('77', 103, 2, 9, 193370) But you have mentioned other obstacles.
('77', 103, 2, 10, 193410) That is the main obstacle.
('77', 103, 2, 11, 193437) But should I not have said, there should be discipline among us?
('77', 103, 3, 12, 193502) But there is discipline.
('77', 103, 3, 13, 193527) We do not start civil disobedience when you say we should not start it.
('77', 103, 3, 14, 193599) I am surprised at the response given by our own leftists.
('77', 103, 3, 15, 193657) Of course one or two of us have talked extreme language, but otherwise there is discipline.
('77', 103, 4, 16, 193749) You, Mahatmaji, will go on waiting and want others also to wait?
('77', 103, 4, 17, 193814) Therefore I have said, don’t have two masters.
('77', 103, 4, 18, 193861) Either convert me or desert me.
('77', 103, 5, 19, 193893) So you have no objection to our starting civil disobedience if we do so after leaving the Congress?
('77', 103, 5, 20, 193993) My objection will have no effect on non Congressmen.
('77', 103, 6, 21, 194046) But we will remain non violent.
('77', 103, 6, 22, 194078) The main obstacle you have mentioned, viz., communal disunity, should be removed.
('77', 103, 6, 23, 194160) I accept it, but after it is removed you won’t resist us.
('77', 103, 6, 24, 194218) On the contrary, if you remain non violent in thought, word and deed, you will make me follow you.
('77', 103, 6, 25, 194317) As I have been telling Prithvi Singh, when he is completely non violent in thought, word and deed I should follow him as he would be very much superior to me.
('77', 103, 6, 26, 194476) So when you are all non violent I should dance with joy.
('77', 103, 7, 27, 194533) You have mentioned hostile acts by Government.
('77', 103, 7, 28, 194580) What have you in mind?
('77', 103, 7, 29, 194603) For example, when they make civil liberty impossible.
('77', 103, 8, 30, 194657) But it is impossible.
('77', 103, 8, 31, 194679) They arrest us even if we speak.
('77', 103, 8, 32, 194712) Do you think it would be a breach of our self imposed vow if we criticize the Government?
('77', 103, 8, 33, 194802) No, if you are not violent in your speech.
('77', 103, 9, 34, 194845) 1 In Delhi, on November 1 and 2 2 Mahadev Desai adds: “Gandhiji gave the friend examples of indiscipline.”
('77', 104, 0, 1, 194952) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 105
('77', 104, 1, 2, 195001) So we can attack Lord Zetland’s speech.

('77', 104, 1, 4, 195155) Oh, yes.

('77', 104, 5, 20, 195832) No, you must not run away with your feelings.
('77', 104, 5, 21, 195878) I assure you, I am capable of saying to the people: ‘Those who are prepared to suffer to the uttermost may refuse to pay.’ But that will not be today.
('77', 104, 5, 22, 196029) The time may come some day—let us hope in my lifetime.
('77', 104, 6, 23, 196084) But is there any harm in doing what the Congress does not ban?
('77', 104, 6, 24, 196147) Everything is banned that the Congress does not advise to be done.
('77', 104, 7, 25, 196214) But if a man feels so strongly about it and wants an escape, how is he to find it?
('77', 104, 7, 26, 196297) By leaving the Congress—which is the only right thing.
('77', 104, 8, 27, 196352) You have asked us to rest content with the constructive programme.
('77', 104, 8, 28, 196419) Now there are full blooded people amongst us.
('77', 104, 8, 29, 196465) They want to do something—something which may not be civil disobedience, but which may lead irresistibly towards it.
('77', 104, 8, 30, 196582) That surely is constructive programme.
('77', 104, 8, 31, 196621) It is surely for the general to decide what that is to be.
('77', 104, 8, 32, 196680) ‘Every man shall walk five miles a day,’ says he, or ‘Everyone shall go and help in emptying a tank, and then march.’ If you believe in observing discipline, don’t you think everyone should do this?
('77', 104, 9, 33, 196879) But we do not know what exactly is to come ultimately.
('77', 104, 9, 34, 196934) You may therefore say that my language is not precise.

('77', 105, 2, 4, 197198) We do not say that the negotiations should not continue and the peace efforts should be relaxed, but we should keep ourselves ready.
