('77', 294, 2, 10, 568116) 357. ADULTERATION OF GHEE
('77', 294, 3, 11, 568142) Dr. Kailas Nath Katju 1 writes : 2
('77', 294, 4, 12, 568177) I have read with great interest in Harijan of 20th January your note 3 on adulteration of ghee.
('77', 294, 4, 13, 568273) The misfortune is that it is not only the ghee dealer and the middleman who have taken to adulteration, but even the ghee producers in the villages are resorting to adulteration in their own homes before they bring ghee to the market.
('77', 294, 4, 14, 568508) We had drafted and introduced in the U.P. Legislature a comprehensive bill to stop this mischief.
('77', 294, 4, 15, 568606) It was at the committee stage when we resigned.
('77', 294, 4, 16, 568654) The bill confers power on the Provincial Government to prescribe colouring or flavouring of artificial ghee or vegetable oils.
('77', 294, 4, 17, 568781) But I think the more useful and really important provision in the bill for the purpose in hand is that which arms the Provincial Government with the power to prohibit sale of artificial or vegetable ghee in ghee producing areas.
('77', 294, 4, 18, 569010) We thought that in such areas where vegetable ghee is really sold for these universal purposes the only proper method is to prohibit its sale altogether, and thus protect and foster the genuine ghee industry.
('77', 294, 4, 19, 569219) The suggestion made by Dr. Katju about specially dealing with ghee producing areas is worthy of consideration.
('77', 294, 4, 20, 569330) Indeed the question of adulteration of this important article of national diet is so important that it requires all India treatment.
('77', 294, 4, 21, 569463) It need not wait for disposal of the so called higher politics.

('77', 295, 5, 23, 570895) 359. A TESTIMONY
('77', 295, 6, 24, 570912) Here is an extract 2 from a letter from Shri Sarangdhar Das, Secretary of the Orissa States People’s Conference : I congratulate Sarangdhar Babu on his conversion.
('77', 295, 6, 25, 571076) I suggest that his conversion will last and be infectious if he studies the implications of the wheel in all its aspects.
('77', 295, 6, 26, 571198) He will then see that the stone hub charkha, which I have seen and turned, is a very primitive contrivance for securing steady motion, but it is a great handicap on the speed.
('77', 295, 6, 27, 571374) He will then apply himself to an improvement of the wheel so that the output of the spinners is doubled, if not trebled.
('77', 295, 6, 28, 571495) This is only one of the many directions in which the charkha spirit can work.
('77', 295, 7, 29, 571573) 1 Gandhiji was to leave Wardha on February 15 on a tour of Bengal and Bihar.
('77', 295, 7, 30, 571650) 2 Not reproduced here.
('77', 295, 7, 31, 571673) It stated how the correspondent, though a believer in machinery and mass production, had become a convert to the cult of the charkha after readingGandhiji’s article on Moral Conscription.
('77', 296, 0, 1, 571861) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 297
('77', 296, 1, 2, 571910) The charkha has its economic, social, political and spiritual aspect.
('77', 296, 1, 3, 571980) It is the last aspect which makes it a symbol of non violence.
('77', 296, 1, 4, 572043) Years ago I reproduced the observations of a Scotch psychologist showing how he used the spinning wheel for curing bad tempered boys.
('77', 296, 1, 5, 572177) He observed that the gentle motion of the wheel produced a soothing and sobering effect on the minds of the subjects.
('77', 296, 1, 6, 572295) I reproduced also the experience of the late Sir Prabhashankar Pattani 1, how he found the wheel a great solace to his jaded nerves when he span for half an hour before retiring.
('77', 296, 1, 7, 572474) Compare Margarete’s song in Faust as she sat at the wheel.
('77', 296, 2, 8, 572533) NEW DELHI, February 5, 1940 Harijan, 10 2 1940
('77', 296, 3, 9, 572580) 360. A GOOD SUGGESTION
('77', 296, 4, 10, 572603) Shrimati Kunverbai Vakil of the Pupils’ Own School, Vile Parle, sends me a parcel of yarn spun by fifteen pupils of the middle class on the Independence Day.
('77', 296, 4, 11, 572761) In a covering letter she says that the commencement in spinning was made by a Harijan pupil and his good example was copied by the others, though not all.
('77', 296, 4, 12, 572916) But Shrimati Kunverbai’s object in writing to me was to draw attention to the fact that for the last three years Principal Vakil and Shrimati Kunverbai Vakil with their pupils have been setting apart four hours for two days in the year to sell khadi.
('77', 296, 4, 13, 573167) The result has been encouraging.
('77', 296, 4, 14, 573200) They were able each time to sell khadi worth Rs. 500 per day.
('77', 296, 4, 15, 573262) She is of opinion that, if all the educational institutions set apart certain days in the year for hawking khadi, there will be a great impetus given to khadi.
('77', 296, 4, 16, 573422) She adds further that since the scholars began to spin and hawk khadi they have been able to introduce khadi in their homes most of which were untouched by it.
('77', 296, 4, 17, 573582) There is no doubt that, if educational institutions take to khadi with the same sincerity and devotion that the Vakils have done, the whole atmosphere will change and khadi will come to its own.
('77', 296, 4, 18, 573777) I have not hesitated to say, and I wish to repeat, that everyone who spins for swaraj brings nearer by so many yards.
('77', 296, 4, 19, 573895) Think what it means if millions were to take part in this grand effort.
('77', 296, 4, 20, 573967) Let no one seek for a parallel in history.
('77', 296, 4, 21, 574010) History has no record of a non violent effort made for a nation’s freedom.
('77', 296, 4, 22, 574085) Bonafide non violent effort presupposes the adoption of unique weapons.
('77', 296, 4, 23, 574157) It is the violence within
('77', 296, 5, 24, 574183) 1 Vide “My Notes”, 9 8 1925; also “Spinning an Art”, 27 5 1926. 2 Vide “Notes”, 4 9 1924.
('77', 297, 0, 1, 574273) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('77', 297, 1, 2, 574315) the breast and the newness of the technique which stand in the way of an appreciation of the charkha.
('77', 297, 1, 3, 574417) I have, therefore, the fear lurking in me that even those who have taken to spinning have done so mechanically and for the sake of discipline.

('77', 299, 9, 37, 578625) 367. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('77', 299, 10, 38, 578653) NEW DELHI, February 6, 1940 The vital difference between the Congress demand and the Viceregal offer consists in the fact that the Viceroy’s offer
('77', 300, 0, 1, 578800) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 301
('77', 300, 1, 2, 578849) contemplates the final determination of India’s destiny by the British Government, whereas the Congress contemplates just the contrary.
('77', 300, 1, 3, 578985) The Congress position is that the test of real freedom consists in the people of India determining their own destiny without any outside influence 1, and I see no prospect whatsoever of a peaceful and honourable settlement between England and India unless the vital difference is obliterated and England decides upon the right course, viz., accepts the position that the time has come when India must be allowed to determine her own constitution and her status.
('77', 300, 1, 4, 579447) When that is done, the question of Defence, the question of minorities, the question of the Princes and the question of the European interest will automatically resolve itself.
('77', 300, 1, 5, 579624) Let me make this a little clearer.
('77', 300, 1, 6, 579659) The provision of safeguards for the rights of minorities is not only common cause between the British Government and the Congress, but the Representative Assembly of Indians cannot evolve a stable Constitution without fullest satisfaction being given to the legitimate minorities.
('77', 300, 1, 7, 579940) I use the word ‘legitimate’ advisedly because I see that minorities crop up like mushrooms, till there will be no majority left.
('77', 300, 1, 8, 580069) By fullest satisfaction I mean satisfaction which will not militate against the progress of the nation as a whole.
('77', 300, 1, 9, 580184) I will, therefore, in the event of differences, refer the question to the highest and most impartial tribunal that can be conceived by human ingenuity.
('77', 300, 1, 10, 580336) Its voice shall be final as to what will amount to the fullest satisfaction of minority interests.
('77', 300, 1, 11, 580435) So far as Defence is concerned, surely it will be the primary concern of free India to make her own arrangements.
('77', 300, 1, 12, 580549) It may well be that India would want elaborate preparation and would want Britain’s help, if it is given, in enabling her to do so.
('77', 300, 1, 13, 580681) Thanks to Imperial policy, unarmed India is left wholly unprotected except by the British bayonet and Indian soldiers whom British power has brought into being.
('77', 300, 1, 14, 580842) It is a position humiliating alike for Britain and for India.
('77', 300, 1, 15, 580904) I am personally unconcerned because, if I could carry India with me, I would want nothing beyond a police force for protection against dacoits and the like.
('77', 300, 1, 16, 581061) But so far as Defence is concerned unarmed peaceful India would rely upon the goodwill of the whole world.
('77', 300, 1, 17, 581168) But I know that that is only a dream at the present moment.
('77', 300, 1, 18, 581228) So far as European interests are concerned, emphasis on the word ‘European’ must be entirely removed.
('77', 300, 1, 19, 581330) But that does not mean
('77', 300, 2, 20, 581353) 1 The Congress Bulletin here has “interference”.
('77', 301, 0, 1, 581402) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('77', 301, 1, 2, 581444) that a free India should be free to confiscate European interests or any other interests.
('77', 301, 1, 3, 581534) There would, as there should, be provision for reasonable compensation for any existing interests which are legitimate and not harmful to the nation.
('77', 301, 1, 4, 581684) It follows that there can be no question of favouritism which is being enjoyed today by European interests.
('77', 301, 1, 5, 581792) I would, therefore, regard them as big zamindars or capitalists.
('77', 301, 1, 6, 581857) They will be put on the same footing as these.
('77', 301, 1, 7, 581904) So far as the Princes are concerned, they are free to join the national assembly which will determine India’s fate not as individuals but as duly elected representatives of their own people.
('77', 301, 1, 8, 582095) The Princes being vassals of the Crown, I fancy they have no status apart from the Crown, and certainly not superior to the Crown itself.
('77', 301, 1, 9, 582233) And if the Crown parts with the power it today enjoys over the whole of India, naturally the Princes have—and it should be their pride—to look up to the successor of the Crown, i.e., the people of India, for the preservation of their status.
('77', 301, 1, 10, 582475) I hope this will not be regarded as a tall claim, for it is made not on behalf of the Congress, nor of any single party, but on behalf of the unrepresented dumb millions of India.
('77', 301, 1, 11, 582655) No claim made on their behalf can be considered too tall.
('77', 301, 1, 12, 582713) I am myself an insignificant being, but I am supposed to have some hold over these dumb millions.
('77', 301, 1, 13, 582811) I know that in every fibre of my being I am also one of them; and without them I am nothing and I do not even want to exist.
('77', 301, 1, 14, 582936) I want on their behalf an honourable settlement with Britain without even a non violent fight.
('77', 301, 1, 15, 583031) My dictionary has no such expression as a violent fight.
('77', 301, 1, 16, 583088) Yesterday I put this view before His Excellency in as courteous and friendly a language as I was capable of using.
('77', 301, 1, 17, 583203) We approached the discussion as personal friends, each believing in the other’s sincerity.
('77', 301, 1, 18, 583294) We understood each other, and both recognized that there still existed a wide gulf between the Government’s position and the position taken by the Congress which I put, though not as an accredited representative of the Congress but certainly as the self appointed representative of the dumb millions.
('77', 301, 1, 19, 583595) We parted as friends.
('77', 301, 1, 20, 583617) I have no disappointment in me that the negotiations have failed.
('77', 301, 1, 21, 583683) That failure I am going to use, as I am sure H. E. the Viceroy is going to use, as a stepping stone to success.
('77', 301, 1, 22, 583795) But if that success does not come in the near future, I can only say Heaven help India, Britain and the world.
('77', 301, 1, 23, 583906) The present war must not be decided by a clash of arms, but it must be decided by the moral strength that
('77', 302, 0, 1, 584012) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 303
('77', 302, 1, 2, 584061) each party can show.
('77', 302, 1, 3, 584082) If Britain cannot recognize India’s legitimate claim, what will it mean but Britain’s moral bankruptcy ?
('77', 302, 1, 4, 584187) Asked regarding the meaning of the words “at this stage” in the sentence “they did not, in his view, at this stage, meet the Congress demand,” 1 Gandhiji said : The phrase in the Government communique “at this stage” is a superfluous phrase.
('77', 302, 1, 5, 584429) If it is interpreted to mean that the Congress may in future modify its demand, it is absolutely unwarranted.
('77', 302, 2, 6, 584539) Asked if there was a chance of the Congress Ministries going back, Gandhiji said : I hope and expect that Congress Ministries will remain out until the main question is settled.
('77', 302, 2, 7, 584717) I don’t see any chance at present of approach between the Congress and the Muslim League.
('77', 302, 2, 8, 584807) I do not see any; because the Muslim League represented by Jinnah Saheb’s letter to me takes up a position which is wholly inimical to the national cause.
('77', 302, 2, 9, 584962) 2 He contemplates several Indias.
('77', 302, 2, 10, 584996) The Congress contemplates only one India.
('77', 302, 3, 11, 585038) When told about the B. B. C. broadcast that Gandhiji was meeting Jinnah Saheb on the evening of the 5th, Gandhiji said : It is staggering how they manufacture news.
('77', 302, 3, 12, 585203) The inventive faculty of man for destruction is showing marvellous resources.

('77', 306, 0, 1, 593081) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 307
('77', 306, 1, 2, 593130) be framed by the Constituent Assembly or an equivalent as soon as practicable.

('77', 312, 6, 9, 603553) 384. THE OLD GAME ?
('77', 312, 7, 10, 603573) After my return from Delhi I have had a letter redirected from New Delhi.
('77', 312, 7, 11, 603647) It is from a valued co worker 1. I must share with all concerned the most important paragraphs in it :
('77', 312, 8, 12, 603750) Everything that has happened during the last month or so confirms me in the belief that there is not the slightest ground for hope that the British Government will accept our position.
('77', 312, 8, 13, 603935) In fact many things have happened which demonstrate that they are following a very definite imperialist policy.
('77', 312, 8, 14, 604047) You must have seen that the British Parliament has just passed a Bill amending the Government of India Act which limits the powers of Provincial Governments in regard to taxation.
('77', 312, 8, 15, 604227) This was specially in view of the Professional Tax 2 in the U.P. which is thus vetoed.
('77', 312, 8, 16, 604314) Apart from the demerit of such a decision which reduces the powers of the Provincial Assembly, the time and the method chosen for it are eloquent of the imperialist outlook of the British Government and indicate that the outlook has in no way changed.
('77', 312, 9, 17, 604566) It is not at all encouraging to find that you are going to New Delhi to interview the Viceroy.
('77', 312, 9, 18, 604661) The same old game is played again, the background is the same, the various objectives are the same, the actors are the same, and the results must be the same.
('77', 312, 10, 19, 604820) There are, however, some unfortunate indirect results also.
('77', 312, 10, 20, 604880) An atmosphere of approaching compromise pervades the country when, in effect, there is no ground for it.
('77', 312, 10, 21, 604985) It is enervating and depressing because it does not come out of strength but, in the case of many individuals, from the excessive desire to avoid conflict at all costs and to get back to the shreds of power
('77', 312, 11, 22, 605192) 1 Jawaharlal Nehru 2 The original in Gandhi Nehru Papers has “Property Tax”.
('77', 313, 0, 1, 605269) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('77', 313, 1, 2, 605311) which we had previously.
('77', 313, 1, 3, 605336) Conflict is undesirable, but obviously conflict cannot be avoided at all costs, for sometimes such avoidance itself is a more costly and harmful affair.
('77', 313, 1, 4, 605489) For the moment, however, there is no immediate question of conflict.
('77', 313, 1, 5, 605558) The question is of maintaining our position with dignity, and not weakening it in any way.
('77', 313, 1, 6, 605649) I fear that the impression is widely prevalent in England as well as in India that we are going in no event to have any conflict and therefore we are going to accept such terms as we can get.
('77', 313, 1, 7, 605841) This kind of impression is demoralizing.
('77', 313, 1, 8, 605882) I have noticed during the last fortnight that even our Congress delegates’ elections have been influenced by this.
('77', 313, 1, 9, 605997) Many people who, for fear of possible conflict, were keeping in the background, have now pushed themselves in front again when the possibility of enjoying the plums of office and power seems to dangle again in front of them.
('77', 313, 1, 10, 606222) The effort of several months to keep undesirables out of the Congress has partly failed because of this sudden change in the Indian atmosphere which led them to believe that the compromise was imminent.
('77', 313, 2, 11, 606425) The British Government is also reacting in a way unfavourable to us, though it may use soft language.
('77', 313, 2, 12, 606527) Of course, it wants to come to terms with us because it wants our support in the war.
('77', 313, 2, 13, 606613) But it is much more certain that it does not wish to give up any shred of real power or change its fundamental imperialist policy in order to come to terms with us.
('77', 313, 2, 14, 606778) It is carrying on and will carry on its old intrigue on the communal issue, though occasionally it uses a few critical words against the Muslim League in order to soothe the Congress.
('77', 313, 2, 15, 606962) So far as it is concerned, it will try to win us over, keeping its present position intact.
('77', 313, 2, 16, 607054) If this is possible, well and good for it.
('77', 313, 2, 17, 607097) If this does not take place, as seems likely even to it [sic], then to carry on from time to time conversations with Indian leaders, to prolong the issue, to make it appear that we are on the verge of a compromise, and thus to soothe both world opinion and Indian opinion.
('77', 313, 2, 18, 607370) This second policy has the additional advantage, from their point of view, of exhausting our energy and toning us down, so that, if ultimately a conflict does come, the requisite atmosphere is lacking for it.
('77', 313, 2, 19, 607579) It is the general belief among official circles in England that their policy of parleys and postponement has had this result and the situation in India, which was threatening when the Congress ministries resigned, is much easier now and no dangers are to be feared.
('77', 313, 3, 20, 607845) It seems to me that while we cannot and must not precipitate a conflict, and while we need not bang the door to a possible and honourable compromise, because your methods are never to bang the door, still we must make it crystal clear that there can be or will be no compromise except on the conditions stated by us previously.
('77', 313, 3, 21, 608173) As a matter of fact, even these conditions have to be slightly reviewed from the point of view of developments in the war.
('77', 313, 3, 22, 608296) We cannot now say, as we then said, that we want to know whether this war is imperialist or not.
('77', 313, 3, 23, 608393) The British Government’s answer to us as well as their consistent policy in the war and in foreign affairs has been one of full 
('77', 314, 0, 1, 608522) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 315
('77', 314, 1, 2, 608571) blooded imperialism.
('77', 314, 1, 3, 608592) We must, therefore necessarily proceed on this admitted fact that it is an imperialist war, any profession to the contrary notwith standing.
('77', 314, 1, 4, 608733) The war and British policy grow more and more sinister every day, and I would hate to see India entangled in any way in this imperialist adventure from which India can only lose, not only materially but spiritually.
('77', 314, 1, 5, 608949) This point seems to me of vital importance today.
('77', 314, 2, 6, 608999) Thus it seems to me that the most important thing for us to do is to make our position perfectly clear to the world, to the British Government and to the Indian people.
('77', 314, 2, 7, 609168) There is too much misunderstanding on this issue of compromise, and this misunderstanding is entirely to our disadvantage and to the advantage of British imperialism which meanwhile is exploiting our resources for the war and even pretending to have a large amount of our goodwill.
('77', 314, 2, 8, 609450) Approach by us to the British Government or to the Viceroy increases these misunderstandings and lead the British Government even further away from a right compromise.
('77', 314, 2, 9, 609618) The warning is sound.
('77', 314, 2, 10, 609640) Perhaps I did not need it.
('77', 314, 2, 11, 609667) But such warnings are never superfluous.
('77', 314, 2, 12, 609708) It is unwise to be too sure of one’s own wisdom.
('77', 314, 2, 13, 609757) It is healthy to be reminded that the strongest might weaken and the wisest might err.
('77', 314, 2, 14, 609844) And then, so far as I am concerned, I am so ignorant even of current events that I feel thankful when co workers keep me posted with things I ought to know.
('77', 314, 2, 15, 610001) But whilst I value the warning given and admit the force of the argument advanced, I do not repent of my having visited H.E. the Viceroy and having had the prolonged talk.
('77', 314, 2, 16, 610173) It has given me added strength.
('77', 314, 2, 17, 610205) It is of great value to an army that its General gains added strength.
('77', 314, 2, 18, 610276) I should therefore repeat the performance every time the Viceroy summons me, i.e., so long as I have faith in his sincerity.
('77', 314, 2, 19, 610401) And every time I shall come out with greater strength than I go with.
('77', 314, 2, 20, 610471) The method of satyagraha requires that the satyagrahi should never lose hope so long as there is the slightest ground left for it.
('77', 314, 2, 21, 610602) For he never despairs of being able to evoke the best in his opponent, his mission being to convert the opponent, not humiliate or defeat him.
('77', 314, 2, 22, 610745) He therefore even knocks at his opponent’s door if it becomes necessary, as I did often with General Smuts.
('77', 314, 2, 23, 610853) It so happened that the last opening, when even I had the least hope, proved the prelude to success.
('77', 314, 2, 24, 610954) There ought not to be demoralization among the ranks.
('77', 314, 2, 25, 611008) It is up to the lieutenants to be in constant touch with them and explain to them the reason for, and the bearing on the struggle of, each step.
('77', 314, 2, 26, 611153) For whether there is actual battle or merely preparation, the education of the masses continues without interruption.
('77', 314, 2, 27, 611271) It is a great mistake to
('77', 315, 0, 1, 611296) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('77', 315, 1, 2, 611338) suppose that the revolutionary instinct will die, if the garnered energies of the people have no outlet.
('77', 315, 1, 3, 611443) This may be true of violent revolution but it is utterly wrong of non violent revolution.
('77', 315, 1, 4, 611533) I am quite convinced that we would put ourselves in the wrong if in our impatience we precipitate the battle or, which is the same thing, bang the door on negotiations.
('77', 315, 1, 5, 611702) The battle will come at the right time when it is clear beyond doubt that there is no escape from it.
('77', 315, 1, 6, 611804) Misunderstanding created in Britain or the world outside need not perturb us much for, being foundationless, it is sure to disappear in the face of our truth.
('77', 315, 1, 7, 611963) Nor need the prospect worry us, of the negotiations proving insincere in the sense of their being used as a screen to cover Britain’s plans to consolidate her strength by misleading world opinion and creating and strengthening divisions among us.
('77', 315, 1, 8, 612210) What does matter is our own weakness for which we alone should be to blame.
('77', 315, 1, 9, 612286) SEGAON, February 11, 1940 Harijan, 17 2 1940
('77', 315, 2, 10, 612331) 385. NOTES
('77', 315, 3, 11, 612342) INDIA WITHOUT THE BRITISH A retired English collector thus cables from England :
('77', 315, 4, 12, 612423) Please consider that India without British troops and the sure shield of the British navy would be at the mercy of Pathans, Afghans and Japan.

('77', 317, 2, 5, 616291) 386. QUESTION BOX
('77', 317, 3, 6, 616309) UNTRUTH IN LAW COURTS
('77', 317, 4, 7, 616331) Q. I have followed with interest the controversy that has grown round your article in Harijan “The Fourfold Ruin” 1. Whatever one may say about the arguments used on either side in this controversy, one thing I am in a position to assert without fear of contradiction, from my experience as a judicial officer of the present system of our law.
('77', 317, 4, 8, 616675) Courts and the institution of lawyers are mainly responsible for the moral and spiritual degradation of our village peasantry in particular and the public in general.
('77', 317, 4, 9, 616842) Even ‘respectable’ people, whom one has learnt to regard as the soul of honour in their ordinary everyday life, will tell barefaced lies for a trifle in a law court and think nothing of it.
('77', 317, 4, 10, 617032) The canker is eating into the vitals of our village life.
('77', 317, 4, 11, 617090) Would you suggest as to what a person in my position, (viz., a judge), who has to record evidence and give judicial decisions, can do to check this evil ?
('77', 317, 5, 12, 617245) A. What you say is too true.
('77', 317, 5, 13, 617274) The atmosphere round law courts is debasing as any visitor passing through them can see.
('77', 317, 5, 14, 617363) I hold radical views about the administration of justice.
('77', 317, 5, 15, 617421) But mine, I know, is a voice in the wilderness.
('77', 317, 5, 16, 617469) Vested interests will not allow radical reform unless India comes into her own through truthful and non violent means.
('77', 317, 5, 17, 617588) If that glorious event happens, the administration of law and medicine will be as cheap and healthy as it is today dear and unhealthy.
('77', 317, 5, 18, 617723) The heroic advice will be for you to descend from the bench, embrace poverty and serve the poor.
('77', 317, 5, 19, 617820) The prosaic will be for you to do the best you can in the very difficult circumstances in which you find yourself, reduce life to its simplest terms and devote your savings for the service of the poor.
('77', 317, 5, 20, 618022) AHIMSA v.
('77', 317, 5, 21, 618032) SELF RESPECT
('77', 317, 6, 22, 618045) Q. I am a university student.
('77', 317, 6, 23, 618075) Yesterday evening some of us went to a cinema show.
('77', 317, 6, 24, 618127) During the performance two of us went outside leaving our handkerchiefs behind on our seats.
('77', 317, 6, 25, 618220) On our return we found that two British soldiers had taken possession of these seats unceremoniously in spite of the clearest warning and
('77', 317, 7, 26, 618358) 1 Vide “Fourfold Ruin”, 28 1 1940.
('77', 318, 0, 1, 618393) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 319
('77', 318, 1, 2, 618442) entreaty by our friends.
('77', 318, 1, 3, 618467) When requested to vacate the seats they not only refused but showed an inclination to fight.
('77', 318, 1, 4, 618560) They browbeat the cinema manager who, being Indian, was easily cowed down.
('77', 318, 1, 5, 618635) In the end the garrison officer was called and they vacated their seats.
('77', 318, 1, 6, 618708) If he had not appeared, there would have been only two alternatives before us, either to resort to violence and maintain our self respect, or to allow ourselves to be browbeaten and quietly occupy some other seats.
('77', 318, 1, 7, 618923) The latter would have been too humiliating.
('77', 318, 1, 8, 618967) How would you apply the principle of non violence under such circumstances ?
('77', 318, 2, 9, 619044) A. I must admit the difficulty of solving the riddle.
('77', 318, 2, 10, 619098) Two ways occur to me of dealing with the situation non violently.
('77', 318, 2, 11, 619164) First, firmly to stand the ground till the seats are vacated; secondly, deliberately so to stand as to obstruct the view of the usurpers.
('77', 318, 2, 12, 619302) In each case you run the risk of being beaten by the usurpers.
('77', 318, 2, 13, 619365) I am not satisfied with my answers.
('77', 318, 2, 14, 619401) But they meet the special circumstances in which we are placed.
('77', 318, 2, 15, 619465) The ideal answer no doubt is not to bother about the usurpation of the personal right but to reason with the usurpers and, if they do not listen, to report such cases to the authorities concerned and, in case of failure, take them to the highest tribunal.
('77', 318, 2, 16, 619721) This is the constitutional method which is not taboo in a non violent conception of society.
('77', 318, 2, 17, 619814) Not to take the law into one’s own hands is essentially a non violent method.
('77', 318, 2, 18, 619892) But the ideal has no relation to reality in this country because the index of expectation of justice for Indians in cases where white men and specially white soldiers are concerned is almost zero.
('77', 318, 2, 19, 620089) Hence it is necessary to resort to something like what I have suggested.
('77', 318, 2, 20, 620162) But I know that when we have real non violence in us a non violent way out is bound, without effort, to occur to us when we find ourselves in a difficult situation.
('77', 318, 3, 21, 620327) STUDENTS AND THE COMING FIGHT
('77', 318, 4, 22, 620357) Q. Although a college student I am a four anna member of the Congress.
('77', 318, 4, 23, 620428) You say I may not take any active part in the coming struggle whilst I am studying.
('77', 318, 4, 24, 620512) What part do you expect the student world to take in the freedom movement ?
('77', 318, 5, 25, 620588) A. There is a confusion of thought in the question.
('77', 318, 5, 26, 620640) The fight is going on now and it will continue till the nation has come to her birthright.
('77', 318, 5, 27, 620731) Civil disobedience is one of the many methods of fighting.
('77', 318, 5, 28, 620790) So far as I can judge today, I have no intention of calling out students.
('77', 318, 5, 29, 620864) Millions will not take part in civil disobedience, but millions will help in a variety of ways.
('77', 318, 5, 30, 620960) 1. Students can, by learning the art of voluntary discipline, fit themselves for leadership in the various branches of the nation’s
('77', 319, 0, 1, 621092) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('77', 319, 1, 2, 621134) 2. They can aim not at finding lucrative careers but at becoming national servants after completing their studies.
('77', 319, 1, 3, 621249) 3. They can set apart for the national coffers a certain sum from their allowances.
('77', 319, 1, 4, 621333) 4. They can promote inter communal, inter provincial and inter caste harmony among themselves and fraternize with Harijans by abolishing the least trace of untouchability from their lives.
('77', 319, 1, 5, 621522) 5. They can spin regularly and use certified khadi to the exclusion of all other cloth as well as hawk khadi.
('77', 319, 1, 6, 621632) 6. They can set apart a certain time every week, if not every day, for service in a village or villages nearest to their institutions and, during the vacation, devote a certain time daily for national service.
('77', 319, 1, 7, 621842) The time may of course come when it may be necessary to call out the students as I did before.
('77', 319, 1, 8, 621937) Though the contingency is remote, it will never come, if I have any say in the matter, unless the students have qualified themselves previously in the manner above described.

('77', 319, 2, 10, 622157) 387. WHAT IS WOMAN’S ROLE ?
('77', 319, 3, 11, 622185) With certain omissions I quote below the following 1 from a highly educated sister :
('77', 319, 4, 12, 622270) You have shown the world, through ahimsa and satyagraha, the dignity of the soul.
('77', 319, 4, 13, 622352) But just as there is need for ahimsa and brahmacharya for a man to get rid of his aggressive spirit, lust .
('77', 319, 4, 14, 622460) ., etc., there is for woman need of certain principles that would enable her to get rid of her baser qualities, which are different from men’s and commonly said to belong by nature to her.
('77', 319, 4, 15, 622649) The natural qualities of her sex, the upbringing meted out to her because of her sex, and her environment which is created because of her sex, all are against her.
('77', 319, 4, 16, 622813) And in her work these things, namely, her nature, upbringing and surroundings always get in the way and hinder her and give occasion for the hackneyed phrase, ‘She is only a woman, after all’ .
('77', 319, 4, 17, 623007) I think that, if we only possess the correct solution, the correct method of improving ourselves, we could make our natural qualities, such as sympathy and tenderness, a help instead of a hindrance.
('77', 319, 4, 18, 623206) The improvement just as your solution in the case of men and children, must come from within us.
('77', 319, 5, 19, 623303) 1 Of which only excerpts are reproduced here
('77', 320, 0, 1, 623348) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 321
('77', 320, 1, 2, 623397) Your advice to me was to read Harijan.

('77', 320, 2, 16, 624549) The soul in both is the same.
('77', 320, 2, 17, 624579) The two live the same life, have the same feelings.

('77', 320, 2, 27, 625352) She is passive, he is active.

('77', 320, 2, 30, 625496) She is the caretaker in every sense of the term.
('77', 320, 2, 31, 625545) The art of bringing up the infants of the race is her special and sole prerogative.
('77', 320, 2, 32, 625629) Without her care the race must become extinct.

('77', 321, 1, 2, 625989) man rides, she brings herself and him down.

('77', 321, 1, 4, 626135) There is as much bravery in keeping one’s home in good order and condition as there is in defending it against attack from without.
('77', 321, 1, 5, 626267) As I have watched millions of peasants in their natural surroundings and as I watch them daily in little Segaon, the natural division of spheres of work has forced itself on my attention.
('77', 321, 1, 6, 626455) There are no women blacksmiths and carpenters.

('77', 321, 1, 14, 627330) I fear I have put the proposition rather clumsily.

('77', 321, 1, 16, 627413) I do not know that the millions of men who are taking an active part in the war are obsessed by the sex spectre.
('77', 321, 1, 17, 627526) Nor are the peasants working together in their fields worried or dominated by it.
('77', 321, 1, 18, 627608) This is not to say or suggest that they are free from the instinct implanted in man and woman.
('77', 321, 1, 19, 627703) But it most certainly does not dominate their lives as it seems to dominate the lives of those who are saturated with the modern sex literature.
('77', 321, 1, 20, 627848) Neither man nor woman has time for such things when he or she is faced with the hard fact of living life in its grim reality.
('77', 321, 1, 21, 627974) I have suggested in these columns that woman is the incarnation of ahimsa.
('77', 321, 1, 22, 628049) Ahimsa means infinite love, which again means infinite capacity for suffering.
('77', 321, 1, 23, 628128) Who but woman, the mother of man, shows this capacity in the largest measure ?
('77', 321, 1, 24, 628207) She shows it as she carries the infant and feeds it during nine months and derives joy in the suffering involved.
('77', 321, 1, 25, 628321) What can beat the suffering caused by the pangs of labour ?
('77', 321, 1, 26, 628381) But she forgets them in the joy of creation.

('77', 322, 0, 1, 628453) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 323
('77', 322, 1, 2, 628502) that her babe may wax from day to day ?
('77', 322, 1, 3, 628542) Let her transfer that love to the whole of humanity, let her forget she ever was or can be the object of man’s lust.
('77', 322, 1, 4, 628659) And she will occupy her proud position by the side of man as his mother, maker and silent leader.
('77', 322, 1, 5, 628757) It is given to her to teach the art of peace to the warring world thirsting for that nectar.
('77', 322, 1, 6, 628850) She can become the leader in satyagraha which does not require the learning that books give but does require the stout heart that comes from suffering and faith.
('77', 322, 1, 7, 629012) My good nurse in the Sassoon Hospital, Poona, as I was lying on a sick bed years ago 1, told me the story of a woman who refused to take chloroform because she would not risk the life of the babe she was carrying.
('77', 322, 1, 8, 629226) She had to undergo a painful operation.

('77', 324, 1, 2, 631674) 391. IS IT WAR ?
('77', 324, 2, 3, 631691) The Builders of the British Indian Empire have patiently built its four pillars—the European interest, the Army, the Princes and the Communal Divisions.
('77', 324, 2, 4, 631844) The last three were to subserve the first.
('77', 324, 2, 5, 631887) It is clear to the realist the Builders have to remove the four pillars before they can claim to have given up the Empire or the Empire spirit.
('77', 324, 2, 6, 632031) But they say to the nationalists or the destroyers of the Empire spirit, ‘You have to deal with all the four pillars yourselves, before we can treat India as an independent nation instead of being our dependency.’ They say in other words, “Guarantee the European interests, make your own army, treat with the Princes and with the communalists otherwise known as minorities.’ The destroyers retort : ‘You imposed the European interest on us, for their defence you built an army and kept it a close preserve, you saw that you could use the then existing Princes for your own purpose, you made them and unmade them, you created new ones, you armed them with powers they could not enjoy before with safety, in fact you partitioned India so that it could never rise against you in one mass.
('77', 324, 2, 7, 632817) You saw again that we were cursed with the caste spirit, you took advantage of our weakness and refined it till at last claims are made which, if they were satisfied, there would be no single Indian nation and no independence.
('77', 324, 2, 8, 633044) Add to all this the fact that by your policy of disarmament you have emasculated a whole nation.
('77', 324, 2, 9, 633141) But we do not blame you for the past.
('77', 324, 2, 10, 633179) On the contrary we admire your bravery, skill and spirit of adventure.
('77', 324, 2, 11, 633250) You have copied other Empire Builders who preceded you.
('77', 324, 2, 12, 633306) You have improved upon them in a variety of ways.
('77', 324, 2, 13, 633356) But if you profess, as you have professed, that you have decided to give India her due, then you have to remove from our way the obstacles you have created.
('77', 324, 2, 14, 633513) You are entitled to ask us to recognize the difficulties in the way of your making delivery and even to help you.
('77', 324, 2, 15, 633627) If you are honest, you will leave us to do the best.
('77', 324, 2, 16, 633680) You must trust our sense of justice, not your strong arm, to make us do what is right and proper.
('77', 324, 2, 17, 633778) Hitherto you have determined our fate for us.
('77', 324, 2, 18, 633824) Now if you are earnest, you will not only let us determine the method and manner of governing ourselves but even help us to do so, if we want your help.’
('77', 325, 0, 1, 633978) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 326
('77', 325, 1, 2, 634020) Lord Zetland has given the answer 1 to the destroyers which I paraphrase as follows : We mean to hold on to what we have.
('77', 325, 1, 3, 634142) Within that orbit, we will let you have such freedom as we think is good for you.
('77', 325, 1, 4, 634224) This war that we are fighting is to prevent the disruption of our Empire.
('77', 325, 1, 5, 634298) We want your help, if you will give it on these terms.
('77', 325, 1, 6, 634353) It is good for you and us.
('77', 325, 1, 7, 634380) But we will do without your help if you will not give it.
('77', 325, 1, 8, 634438) You are not the only party we have to deal with.
('77', 325, 1, 9, 634487) There are many in India who recognize the benefits of British Rule and pax Britannica.
('77', 325, 1, 10, 634574) We propose to win the war with the help we can command from India through the loyal agencies.
('77', 325, 1, 11, 634668) Their services we shall recognize by the grant of further reforms when the time comes.
('77', 325, 1, 12, 634755) This is what we mean when we say we shall make the world safe for democracy.
('77', 325, 1, 13, 634832) For we are the most democratic power in the world.
('77', 325, 1, 14, 634883) Therefore, if we are safe, so are those who are with us.
('77', 325, 1, 15, 634940) Those like India who are under our tutelage will be initiated into the art of democracy in gradual stages so that their progress may be uninterrupted and they might not have to go through the travail we had to go through.
('77', 325, 1, 16, 635162) I hope the paraphrase does no injustice to Lord Zetland.
('77', 325, 1, 17, 635219) If it is fairly correct, the issues are quite clear.
('77', 325, 1, 18, 635272) Between the two—the Nationalist and the Imperialist—there is no meeting ground.
('77', 325, 1, 19, 635352) If, therefore, Lord Zetland represents the British Government’s considered view, it is a declaration of war against nationalist India.
('77', 325, 1, 20, 635487) For all the four pillars stand firm, rock like.
('77', 325, 1, 21, 635535) The more the nationalists try to deal with them as if they were problems for which they were responsible, the firmer they must become.
('77', 325, 1, 22, 635670) I cannot conscientiously pray for the success of British arms if it means a further lease of life to India’s subjection to foreign domination.
('77', 325, 1, 23, 635813) I write this last sentence with a heavy heart.

('77', 329, 3, 7, 640481) 398. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 2
('77', 329, 4, 8, 640511) SEGAON, February 14, 1940 Lord Zetland’s recent pronouncement, 3 if reported correctly, sets at rest all speculation regarding the Government’s attitude towards the nationalist demand.
('77', 329, 4, 9, 640696) I have been taught to believe that Dominion Status after the Statute of Westminster pattern is akin to independence and includes the right to secede.
('77', 329, 4, 10, 640846) Therefore, I had thought there would be no difficulty about Britain allowing India to determine her own status.
('77', 329, 4, 11, 640958) But Lord Zetland makes it clear that Britain, not India, has to determine it.
('77', 329, 4, 12, 641036) In other words, the British hold on India must remain.
('77', 329, 4, 13, 641091) He also puts the burden upon the nationalists of solving the minorities question and the like.
('77', 329, 4, 14, 641186) I have shown 4 how impossible this is without previous recognition of India’s independence, no doubt subject to safeguards.
('77', 329, 4, 15, 641310) His Lordship thinks that, because some Indians have
('77', 329, 5, 16, 641362) 1 Referring to Gandhiji’s article, vide “The Charkha”, 9 1 1940, the addressee had pleaded with him not to be harsh with Subhas Chandra Bose who was then in indifferent health.
('77', 329, 5, 17, 641539) 2 This appeared in Harijan under the title “Banging the Door”.
('77', 329, 5, 18, 641602) 3 The Secretary of State for India said that experience of the working of the constitution in the Act of 1935 had made it clear that the problem of the minorities must be taken in hand by Indians themselves.
('77', 329, 5, 19, 641810) “Long range bombardment by leading personalities from platform and Press is little likely to lead anywhere.
('77', 329, 5, 20, 641918) What is wanted is escape from the tyranny of phrases and a descent from idealism, from the abstract to the concrete.
('77', 329, 5, 21, 642035) I believe that only by means of discussions among those who can speak with authority for their followers, informal and in confidence in the first instance, is helpful appreciation of their respective standpoints and difficulties inherent in them to be hoped for.
('77', 329, 5, 22, 642298) If such a discussion is to be faithful, there must be on all sides a genuine will to succeed and a real spirit of compromise.
('77', 329, 5, 23, 642424) The British Government cannot compel these things : they can only plead for them as I most earnestly do.” Vide also “Another Englishman’s Letter”, 16 3 1940. 4Vide “Is It War ?”, 13 2 1940.
('77', 330, 0, 1, 642614) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 331
('77', 330, 1, 2, 642663) received the boon of English education and have learnt ideas of freedom from British writers, they will want always to be under British tutelage euphemistically called partnership.
('77', 330, 1, 3, 642844) This is what I call banging the door upon the nationalist position.
('77', 330, 1, 4, 642912) Does it mean a pact deadlier than was announced at the last Round Table Conference 1 ?
('77', 330, 1, 5, 642999) If it does, it is a declaration of war against nationalists who are out to destroy the empire spirit.

('77', 330, 4, 13, 643480) PYARELAL, I have picked up the pen but God alone knows if I shall be able to write what I have to write.
('77', 330, 4, 14, 643585) My step is towards the quest of truth.
('77', 330, 4, 15, 643624) It dawned on me that I was following the path of untruth.
('77', 330, 4, 16, 643682) Yesterday the turmoil in my mind was beyond endurance.
('77', 330, 4, 17, 643737) My decision has become a secondary atter.
('77', 330, 4, 18, 643779) The great thing is the background of that decision.
('77', 330, 4, 19, 643831) And what is the untruth?
('77', 330, 4, 20, 643856) Well, there is Sushila.
('77', 330, 4, 21, 643880) I take her as an example.
('77', 330, 4, 22, 643906) It was an untruth to let her believe that I am keeping her as my physician.
('77', 330, 4, 23, 643982) I wanted to draw her to me.
('77', 330, 4, 24, 644010) The reasons are many.
('77', 330, 4, 25, 644032) But all of them put together would not have attracted her.
('77', 330, 4, 26, 644091) So I let her believe that she is with me as my physician.
('77', 330, 4, 27, 644149) I would consider it sinful to have her principally as my physician.
('77', 330, 4, 28, 644217) I would consider it the proper thing for her to give me medical care while doing my other work.
('77', 330, 4, 29, 644313) This would not always include her travelling with me.
('77', 330, 4, 30, 644367) Whatever work I entrusted to her would be service done to me.
('77', 330, 4, 31, 644429) And while doing that work she could also look after my medical needs and be content.
('77', 330, 4, 32, 644514) This attitude of ‘all or nothing’ is a great mistake.
('77', 330, 4, 33, 644568) How long am I going to live?
('77', 330, 4, 34, 644597) How can she have the heart to leave me?
('77', 330, 4, 35, 644637) Why does she forget that she does so many other jobs for me?
('77', 330, 4, 36, 644698) I consider it sheer obstinacy on her part even to overlook the fact that her presence will give you the satisfaction of being near her.

('77', 334, 1, 2, 650581) 404. LETTER TO SHAMBHUSHANKAR TRIVEDI
('77', 334, 2, 3, 650619) SEGAON, February 15, 1940
('77', 334, 3, 4, 650645) SHAMBHUSHANKAR, I keep on getting news of you.
('77', 334, 3, 5, 650692) Some friends write to me that I prompted you to undertake the fast.
('77', 334, 3, 6, 650760) I hope you don’t think so.
('77', 334, 3, 7, 650787) Let me state my position.
('77', 334, 3, 8, 650813) I have no right to recommend a fast to you or to anyone.
('77', 334, 3, 9, 650870) A fast may be undertaken only when prompted from within.
('77', 334, 3, 10, 650927) Hence this attitude on my part.
('77', 334, 3, 11, 650959) You write that there was a clear breach of promise.
('77', 334, 3, 12, 651011) You broke your fast after you had secured the promise.
('77', 334, 3, 13, 651066) Then you asked me whether it was contrary to dharma to undertake it now that the promise was broken.
('77', 334, 3, 14, 651167) And I replied that it was not so, in fact it could be your dharma.
('77', 334, 3, 15, 651234) Hence if you have the slightest doubt please give up the fast.
('77', 334, 3, 16, 651297) If you have no doubts, may God grant you the strength to hold fast to your resolve.
('77', 334, 3, 17, 651381) I am happy to know that you are at peace.
('77', 334, 3, 18, 651423) May your peace of mind last for ever.

('77', 334, 5, 22, 651548) 405. QUESTION BOX
('77', 334, 6, 23, 651566) UNITY v.
('77', 334, 6, 24, 651575) JUSTICE
('77', 334, 7, 25, 651583) Q. In your article “Unity v.
('77', 334, 7, 26, 651612) Justice” 1 you say that, if you give more than his due to your brother, you neither bribe him nor do you do an injustice.
('77', 334, 7, 27, 651734) You say : “I can disarm suspicion only by being generous.
('77', 334, 7, 28, 651792) Justice without generosity is done at the expense of the very cause for which it is sought to be done.” I submit that justice and generosity cannot go hand in hand.
('77', 334, 7, 29, 651957) As Dryden has rightly observed, “Justice is blind, it knows nobody.” Besides, you can be generous to the weak, meek and the humble, not to one who in the arrogance of his strength seeks to coerce you into submission.
('77', 334, 7, 30, 652174) To give more than his due to such a person is not generosity but cowardly surrender.
('77', 334, 7, 31, 652259) Though Hindus are numerically stronger, their majority, as you yourself have pointed out, is only fictitious and actually they are the weaker party.
('77', 334, 7, 32, 652408) Besides, if generosity is to be shown to the Muslims, the only organization that is competent to offer it is the Hindu Mahasabha.
('77', 334, 7, 33, 652538) What right has a third party to be generous to one of the two
('77', 334, 8, 34, 652600) 1Vide “Unity v.
('77', 334, 8, 35, 652616) Justice”, 23 1 1940.
('77', 335, 0, 1, 652637) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 336
('77', 335, 1, 2, 652679) parties to a dispute at the other party’s expense ?
('77', 335, 2, 3, 652731) A. In my article referred to by you I have dealt with general principles, not with particular minorities.
('77', 335, 2, 4, 652837) Even as justice to be justice has to be generous, generosity in order to justify itself has got to be strictly just.
('77', 335, 2, 5, 652954) Therefore it should not be at the expense of any single interest.
('77', 335, 2, 6, 653020) Hence there cannot be any question of sacrificing some minority or minorities, for the benefit of any minority.
('77', 335, 2, 7, 653132) You are right again in con tending that generosity has to be shown to the weak and the humble, and not to the bully.
('77', 335, 2, 8, 653249) Nevertheless I would say, on behalf of the bully, that even he is entitled to justice, for immediately you brush aside the bully and be unjust to him you justify his bullying.
('77', 335, 2, 9, 653425) Thus the only safe—not to put it higher—rule of conduct is to do generous justice, irrespective of the character of the minority.
('77', 335, 2, 10, 653555) I am quite sure that where there is strictest justice the question of a majority and minority would not arise.
('77', 335, 2, 11, 653666) The bully is a portent and is an answer to some existing circumstance, as, for instance, cowardice.
('77', 335, 2, 12, 653766) It is often forgotten that cowardice can be unjust.
('77', 335, 2, 13, 653818) The fact is that cowards have no sense of justice.
('77', 335, 2, 14, 653869) They yield only to threat, or actual use of force.
('77', 335, 2, 15, 653920) I do not know that there is any question of choice between a coward and a bully.
('77', 335, 2, 16, 654001) The one is as bad as the other, with this difference that the bully always follows the coward in point of time.
('77', 335, 2, 17, 654113) In a previous issue I have admitted that the proper organization to enter into settlements is the Hindu Mahasabha, so far as Hindus are concerned, or any such organization.
('77', 335, 2, 18, 654286) 1 The Congress endeavours to represent all communities.
('77', 335, 2, 19, 654342) It is not by design, but by the accident of Hindus being politically more conscious than the others, that the Congress contains a majority of Hindus.
('77', 335, 2, 20, 654492) As history proves the Congress is a joint creation of Muslims, Christians, Parsis, Hindus, led by Englishmen, be it said to the credit of the latter.
('77', 335, 2, 21, 654642) And the Congress, in spite of all that may be said to the contrary, retains that character.
('77', 335, 2, 22, 654734) At the present moment a Muslim divine is the unquestioned leader of the Congress and for the second time becomes its President.
('77', 335, 2, 23, 654862) 2 The constant endeavour of Congressmen has been to have as many members as possible drawn from the various communities, and therefore the Congress has entered into pacts for the purpose of securing national solidarity.
('77', 335, 2, 24, 655082) It cannot, therefore, divest itself of that
('77', 335, 3, 25, 655126) 1 Vide “Is Congress a Hindu Organisation?”, 13 11 1939 2 Abul Kalam Azad was President elect of the forthcoming Congress session at Ramgarh.
('77', 336, 0, 1, 655267) VOL. 77 : 16 OCTOBER, 1939 22 FEBRUARY, 1940 337
('77', 336, 1, 2, 655316) function, and therefore, although I have made the admission that the Hindu Mahasabha or a similar Hindu organization can properly have communal settlements, the Congress cannot and must not plead incapacity for entering into political pacts so long as it commands general confidence.

('77', 336, 2, 4, 655663) 406. NOTES
('77', 336, 3, 5, 655674) CLEAR INJUSTICE The Secretary of the Seng Khasi Free Morning School, Mawkhar, Shillong, has sent a circular letter to those who are concerned in matters educational and has favoured me also with a copy.
('77', 336, 3, 6, 655877) I extract the following from it : 1
('77', 336, 4, 7, 655913) The British Government gave education grants to the Christian missionaries for spreading education among the people of the Khasi and Jaintia Hills District.
('77', 336, 4, 8, 656070) The missionaries printed the textbooks for schools according to their liking and choice.
('77', 336, 4, 9, 656159) They translated the Bible into Khasi language and made it a textbook for schools.
('77', 336, 4, 10, 656241) Some pure Khasi gentlemen .
('77', 336, 4, 11, 656269) started the Seng Khasi Free Morning School as early as 1921, with a view to preserving Khasi national culture.
('77', 336, 4, 12, 656380) The Deputy Inspector of Schools, Khasi and Jaintia Hills, desired us to follow the curriculum prescribed by his department.
('77', 336, 4, 13, 656504) I agreed to accept the curriculum provided that those books written or compiled by the missionaries are not included in the curriculum of the Seng Khasi School.
('77', 336, 4, 14, 656665) The Deputy Inspector of Schools did not recommend this school for a grant from the Government on the plea that the curriculum was not followed in the school.
('77', 336, 4, 15, 656823) It is a matter of great regret that the Deputy Inspector of Schools compels this school to teach missionary books and frustrate the very object with which it was established.
('77', 336, 4, 16, 656998) If what is stated here is true, it enforces the argument often advanced by me that Christian missionary effort has been favoured by the ruling power.
('77', 336, 4, 17, 657148) But I advertise the circular not for the sake of emphasizing my argument.
('77', 336, 4, 18, 657222) I do so in order to ventilate the grievance of the Secretary of the school.
('77', 336, 4, 19, 657298) Surely he has every right to object to teaching proselytizing literature prepared by the missionaries.
('77', 336, 4, 20, 657401) It should be remem bered that the school has been in receipt of a grant from Government.
('77', 336, 4, 21, 657490) It is not clear why the question of the missionary books has now cropped up.
('77', 336, 4, 22, 657567) It is to be hoped that the school will not
('77', 336, 5, 23, 657610) 1Only excerpts are reproduced here,
('77', 337, 0, 1, 657646) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 338
('77', 337, 1, 2, 657688) be deprived of the grant because of the Secretary’s very reasonable objection.
('77', 337, 1, 3, 657767) SKIMMED MILK Prof.
('77', 337, 1, 4, 657786) Warner of Allahabad Agricultural Institute sends me a copy of a note submitted by him to a Municipal Board in U. P. The Board has passed a bye law requiring that “all skimmed milk sold in the city should be coloured in order that it may be easily identified as skimmed milk, thereby preventing its use in diluting or adulterating whole milk.” Prof.
('77', 337, 1, 5, 658135) Warner is of opinion that this is a dangerous bye law whose effect would be total destruction of a valuable protective food.
('77', 337, 1, 6, 658260) He has shown in the note, I think conclusively, that skimmed milk as an article of food is not to be despised, the only difference between whole milk and skimmed milk being that a large percentage of fat is removed from skimmed milk for preparing butter, but the milk retains all the salts and all the proteins.
('77', 337, 1, 7, 658572) Adulteration, therefore, of whole milk with skimmed milk produces very little effect upon its nutritive value.
('77', 337, 1, 8, 658683) Only the percentage of fat is reduced somewhat.
('77', 337, 1, 9, 658731) He gives figures in support of his argument which I need not reproduce.
('77', 337, 1, 10, 658803) He does not mind bye laws preventing adulteration even with skimmed milk.
('77', 337, 1, 11, 658877) But he strongly objects, and I think rightly, to destroying skimmed milk by colouring it, and he shows that not only is a valuable article of diet taken away from the mouths of poor people, but the danger of adulteration of milk with water increases.
('77', 337, 1, 12, 659128) And this danger is very real, because the greater the percentage of water the lower is the nutritive value of milk.
('77', 337, 1, 13, 659244) And add to this the fact that the water itself may be impure.
('77', 337, 1, 14, 659306) Warner draws a distinction between requiring the colouring of vegetable ghee for preventing adulteration of real ghee, and the colouring of skimmed milk.
('77', 337, 1, 15, 659460) It is wholly necessary that vegetable ghee should be coloured with some innocuous dye.
('77', 337, 1, 16, 659547) Coloured vegetable ghee will be used by the people for its cheapness.
('77', 337, 1, 17, 659617) But as there is already prejudice against skimmed milk people will refuse to take coloured skimmed milk, even though the colouring matter may be utterly innocuous.
('77', 337, 1, 18, 659781) I would on my own behalf enforce Prof.
('77', 337, 1, 19, 659820) Warner’s argument by suggesting that municipalities will do well to popularize the use of skimmed milk.
('77', 337, 1, 20, 659924) It can be sold very cheap and it is a perfectly wholesome thing both for the rich and the poor, and is a good sick man’s diet, when whole milk is rejected by the digestive apparatus.

('77', 338, 1, 2, 660218) 407. SPEECH AT SANTINIKETAN 1
('77', 338, 2, 3, 660248) February 17, 1940 My uppermost feelings on arriving here are about Deenaban dhu 2. Perhaps you do not know that the first thing I did yesterday morning on alighting from the train at Calcutta was to pay him a visit in the hospital.
('77', 338, 2, 4, 660480) Gurudev is a world poet, but Deenabandhu too has the spirit and temperament of a poet in him.
('77', 338, 2, 5, 660574) He had long yearned to be present on the present occasion, to drink in and store up the memory of every word, movement and gesture relating to the meeting with Gurudev.
('77', 338, 2, 6, 660743) But God had willed it otherwise and he now lies in Calcutta, stricken down and unable even to make full use of his speech.
('77', 338, 2, 7, 660866) I would like you all to join me in the prayer that God may restore him to us soon, and, in any case, may grant his spirit peace.
('77', 338, 2, 8, 660995) I know what love Gurudev has for me.
('77', 338, 2, 9, 661032) 3 I recollect the early days of the Ashram in 1915 when I had nowhere to lay my head.
('77', 338, 2, 10, 661118) I have not come here as a stranger or a guest.
('77', 338, 2, 11, 661165) Santiniketan has been more than a home to me.
('77', 338, 2, 12, 661211) It was here that the members of my South African family found warm hospitality in 1914, pending my arrival from England, and I too found shelter here for nearly a month.
('77', 338, 2, 13, 661381) The memories of those days crowd in upon me as I see you all here, assembled before me.
('77', 338, 2, 14, 661469) It grieves me that I cannot prolong my stay here as I would have loved to.
('77', 338, 2, 15, 661544) It is a question of duty.
('77', 338, 2, 16, 661570) In a letter to a friend, the other day, I described my present trip to Santiniketan and Malikanda as a pilgrimage.
('77', 338, 2, 17, 661685) Santiniketan has truly, this time, proved

('77', 338, 3, 20, 662011) Homage to the great naturally seeks its manifestation in the language of simplicity and we offer you these few words to let you know that we accept you as our own, as one belonging to all humanity.

('77', 342, 3, 7, 667333) 415. DISCUSSION WITH PACIFISTS 3
('77', 342, 4, 8, 667366) [On or before February 19, 1940] 4
('77', 342, 5, 9, 667401) [Q.] Supposing in the presence of superior brute force one feels helpless, would one be justified in using just enough force to prevent the perpetration of wrong ?
('77', 342, 5, 10, 667565) [A.] Yes, but there need not be that feeling of helplessness if there is real non violence in you.
('77', 342, 5, 11, 667664) To feel helpless in the presence of violence is not non violence but cowardice.
('77', 342, 5, 12, 667744) Non violence should not be mixed up with cowardice.
('77', 342, 6, 13, 667796) Suppose someone came and hurled insult at you, should you allow yourself to be thus humiliated ?
('77', 342, 6, 14, 667893) If you feel humiliated, you will be justified in slapping the bully in the face or taking whatever action you might deem nece ssary to vindicate your self respect.
('77', 342, 6, 15, 668057) The use of force, under the circumstances, would be the natural consequence if you are not a coward.
('77', 342, 6, 16, 668158) But there should be no feeling of humiliation in you if you have assimilated the non violence spirit.
('77', 342, 6, 17, 668260) Your non violent behaviour would then either make the bully feel ashamed of himself and prevent the insult, or
('77', 342, 7, 18, 668371) 1 As Gandhiji was about to leave after visiting the rural reconstruction centre of the Visvabharati he was asked to say a few words.

('77', 343, 1, 2, 668997) make you immune against it so that the insult would remain only in the bully’s mouth and not touch you at all.
('77', 343, 2, 3, 669108) Supposing there is a person with a diseased mind—a lunatic run amuck, bent upon murder, or you arrive on the scene of trouble when the situation has already advanced too far.
('77', 343, 2, 4, 669283) An infuriated mob has got out of hand, and you feel helpless, would you justify the use of physical force to restrain the lunatic in the first case, or allow the use, say, of tear gas in the latter ?
('77', 343, 2, 5, 669483) I will excuse it for all time.
('77', 343, 2, 6, 669514) But I would not say it is justified from the non violent standpoint.
('77', 343, 2, 7, 669583) I would say that there was not that degree of non violence in you to give you confidence in purely non violent treatment.
('77', 343, 2, 8, 669705) If you had, your simple presence would be sufficient to pacify the lunatic.
('77', 343, 2, 9, 669781) Non violence carries within it its own sanction.
('77', 343, 2, 10, 669830) It is not a mechanical thing.
('77', 343, 2, 11, 669860) You do not become non violent by merely saying, ‘I shall not use force.’ It must be felt in the heart.
('77', 343, 2, 12, 669963) There must be within you an upwelling of love and pity towards the wrongdoer.
('77', 343, 2, 13, 670041) When there is that feeling it will express itself through some action.
('77', 343, 2, 14, 670112) It may be a sign, a glance, even silence.
('77', 343, 2, 15, 670154) But such as it is it will melt the heart of the wrongdoer and check the wrong.
('77', 343, 2, 16, 670233) The use of tear gas is not justified in terms of the non violent ideal.
('77', 343, 2, 17, 670305) But I would defend its use against the whole world if I found myself in a corner when I could not save a helpless girl from violation or prevent an infuriated crowd from indulging in madness, except by its use.
('77', 343, 2, 18, 670516) God would not excuse me if, on the Judgment Day, I were to plead before Him that I could not prevent these things from happening because I was held back by my creed of non violence.
('77', 343, 2, 19, 670698) Non violence is self acting.
('77', 343, 2, 20, 670727) A fully non violent person is by nature incapable of using violence or rather has no use for it.
('77', 343, 2, 21, 670824) His non violence is all sufficing under all circumstances.
('77', 343, 2, 22, 670883) Therefore, when I say that the use of force is wrong in whatever degree and under whatever circumstances, I mean it in a relative sense.
('77', 343, 2, 23, 671020) It is much better for me to say I have not sufficient non violence in me, than to admit exceptions to an eternal principle.
('77', 343, 2, 24, 671144) Moreover my refusal to admit exceptions spurs me to perfect myself in the technique of non violence.
('77', 343, 2, 25, 671245) I literally believe in Patanjali’s aphorism that violence ceases in the presence of non violence.
('77', 343, 3, 26, 671343) Can a State carry on strictly according to the principle of non violence ?
('77', 343, 3, 27, 671418) A Government cannot succeed in becoming entirely non

('77', 344, 1, 2, 671533) violent, because it represents all the people.
('77', 344, 1, 3, 671580) I do not today conceive of such a golden age.
('77', 344, 1, 4, 671626) But I do believe in the possibility of a predominantly non violent society.
('77', 344, 1, 5, 671702) And I am working for it.
('77', 344, 1, 6, 671727) A Government representing such society will use the least amount of force.

('77', 344, 3, 10, 672003) 416. COMMUNAL DECISION
('77', 344, 4, 11, 672026) During my brief stay in Bengal I have been overwhelmed with questions on the Communal Decision.
('77', 344, 4, 12, 672122) I have been told that neither the Working Committee nor I have pronounced decisive opinion on it.
('77', 344, 4, 13, 672220) The Working Committee’s decision is written in its records and has been published.
('77', 344, 4, 14, 672303) 2 It has neither accepted nor rejected the Decision.
('77', 344, 4, 15, 672356) There can be neither acceptance nor rejection of an imposed thing.
('77', 344, 4, 16, 672423) A prisoner is not required to accept the sentence pronounced against him.
('77', 344, 4, 17, 672497) His rejection would be meaningless.
('77', 344, 4, 18, 672533) For he would soon find himself undeceived.
('77', 344, 4, 19, 672576) The Communal Decision has been imposed upon India not for her own good but for strengthening the British imperial hold on India.
('77', 344, 4, 20, 672705) The Working Committee has, therefore, as much accepted and as much rejected the Decision as Bengal has.
('77', 344, 4, 21, 672809) There is this difference, however, that the Working Committee has not agitated against it like Bengal.
('77', 344, 4, 22, 672912) For me, I detest the Decision.
('77', 344, 4, 23, 672943) It has benefited no single party in India but the British.
('77', 344, 4, 24, 673002) If the Muslims flatter themselves with the belief that they have profited by it, they will soon find that they were sadly mistaken.
('77', 344, 4, 25, 673134) If I could alter the Decision and make it what it should be, I should do so this very moment.
('77', 344, 4, 26, 673228) But I have no such power.
('77', 344, 4, 27, 673254) The power can only come if there is unity.
('77', 344, 4, 28, 673297) Bengal is the most glaring instance of injustice.
('77', 344, 4, 29, 673347) I can conceive of no just reason for putting the wedge of the tremendous European vote between the two major communities.
('77', 344, 4, 30, 673469) Their number is insignificant.
('77', 344, 4, 31, 673500) Their interest is protected by the British bayonet.
('77', 344, 4, 32, 673552) Why should that interest have added strength given to it by

('77', 345, 1, 2, 673848) its introduction in the legislature ?

('77', 345, 1, 4, 673994) So long as it has the protection of the British bayonet, its over representation on the legislature is a wholly unjust imposition.

('77', 349, 4, 7, 680913) 423. SPEECH AT KHADI AND VILLAGE INDUSTRIES EXHIBITION 1
('77', 349, 5, 8, 680970) MALIKANDA, February 20, 1940 If you remain quiet, my voice will reach you.
('77', 349, 5, 9, 681045) I just now heard some people shouting “Down with Gandhism”.
('77', 349, 5, 10, 681105) Those who want to put down Gandhism have every right to say so.
('77', 349, 5, 11, 681169) Those who have come to hear me will please keep quiet and not get excited by hostile slogans nor shout counter slogans of “Gandhijiki Jai”.
('77', 349, 5, 12, 681309) If you are non violent, you should calmly tolerate such slogans.
('77', 349, 5, 13, 681374) If there is any trace of untruth in Gandhism, it must perish.
('77', 349, 5, 14, 681436) If it contains truth, lakhs and crores of voices clamouring for its destruction will not destroy it.
('77', 349, 5, 15, 681537) Allow freedom to those who want to say anything against Gandhism.
('77', 349, 5, 16, 681603) That will cause no harm.
('77', 349, 5, 17, 681628) Do not bear any grudge or malice against them.
('77', 349, 5, 18, 681675) You cannot realize ahimsa unless you can calmly tolerate your opponents.
('77', 349, 5, 19, 681748) In truth, I myself do not know what Gandhism means.
('77', 349, 5, 20, 681800) I have not given anything new to the country.
('77', 349, 5, 21, 681846) I have only given a new form to the traditional [wisdom] of India.
('77', 349, 5, 22, 681913) It would therefore be wrong to call it Gandhism.
('77', 349, 5, 23, 681962) We have not assembled here for any political activity.
('77', 349, 5, 24, 682017) We have come here to devise ways and means for fulfilling the principal objective of the Gandhi Seva Sangh.
('77', 349, 5, 25, 682125) I cordially invite those who shouted hostile slogans to say whatever they like and give vent to their views.
('77', 349, 5, 26, 682234) Why should we look upon each other as enemies ?
('77', 349, 5, 27, 682282) What if our views differ ?
('77', 349, 5, 28, 682309) We should remain friends because we all love India and want her to be free.
('77', 349, 5, 29, 682385) One party follows one path and another party prefers a different path; but our goal remains the same.
('77', 349, 5, 30, 682487) Why then should there be any enmity ?

('77', 401, 4, 5, 811906) November 23, 1939
('77', 401, 5, 6, 811924) MY DEAR BHAI,
('77', 401, 6, 7, 811938) Pyarelal has been good enough to send us news of you and your message of love and affection, for which we are grateful to you and to him.
('77', 401, 6, 8, 812076) Of course, we understand how busy you must be and how necessary it is for you to deal with immediate matters and correspondence first.
('77', 401, 6, 9, 812211) We know, too, from old experience, that “the nearest and the dearest” must be prepared to make the hardest sacrifice!
('77', 401, 6, 10, 812329) It is good to feel that in spite of time and circumstances, we are still included in that category.
('77', 401, 6, 11, 812429) Indeed, it must have been in our karma that this close link between us, which has remained unbroken for so long, should have been forged.
('77', 401, 7, 12, 812567) We are three families here (Shiplake, near Henley on Thames, Oxon.) in a small house by the river Millie, Celie and I; Leon’s wife, Marie, and the two children (the elder, Rosemary, nearly five, a most energetic, exigent, and eager little girl, and the boy, Peter, aged 21 months, fat, fine, and full of good humour and intelligence); and Millie’s other sister and her husband; not to speak of a maid and two dogs.
('77', 401, 7, 13, 812982) So you can well imagine how full of domestic activity and responsibility Millie is.
('77', 401, 7, 14, 813066) Indeed, she is giving all her time to these duties.
('77', 401, 7, 15, 813118) Her health, despite the fact that she had no holiday this summer, owing to the outbreak of war just after everyone else had one, and that she had a shocking scalding accident when visiting Mater in June (the latter is over 80 and in fairly good health and spirit, at Bexhill), is on the whole pretty good, though, naturally, as the strain does not get less, she has spells of fatigue, which affect the nerves and the heart, from time to time.
('77', 401, 7, 16, 813561) She shares with you, though in a much less degree, a tendency to blood pressure.
('77', 401, 8, 17, 813642) The war is in background of all our lives.
('77', 401, 8, 18, 813685) When the worst will be reached none can say.
('77', 401, 8, 19, 813730) But the general determination of the country to try to end the constant pressure of threats, agression and violence is unmistakeable; and so, in spite of an undercurrent of anxiety and uncertainty, there is a deeply ingrained satisfaction that a great effort is being made to establish once more the basis of something more than a nominal peace and a return to a more civilised handling of the problems of life, personal, rational, and international.
('77', 401, 9, 20, 814181) For ourselves, we are hoping to stay out at Shiplake till the end of the war.
('77', 401, 9, 21, 814259) Leon is an Air Raid Protection Warden in charge of his area, near his house in Wimbledon, of some square miles.
('77', 401, 9, 22, 814371) He comes down whenever possible at weekends, and sometimes instead, Marie goes up to him, to say that the house is still there and
('77', 401, 10, 23, 814502) 1 Vide “Letter to H. S. L. Polak”, August 30, 1941.

('77', 402, 1, 4, 814674) For reasons of security, the firm has transferred most of the professional work and the records to new offices at Wimbledon, whilst retaining some of the old offices in the Strand, where we attend two days a week.

('77', 402, 2, 9, 815273) As you will no doubt have surmised, none of these jobs weighs more heavily upon me than our old problems of Indians overseas and, in particular, those of South Africa.
('77', 402, 2, 10, 815441) So soon as General Hertzog resigned, I wrote to General Smuts and Dr.J.H. Hofmeyr, as you will see from the enclosed correspondence, and received from then the enclosed replies, which I have communicated to Lord Zetland, Mr.Anthony Eden at the Dominions Office ( who have both warmly acknowledged them), the Government of India, and the Indian Agent General (Sir B.Rama Rau); and this week I have discussed the situation in an intimate and informal talk with Colonel Deneys Reitz, the Union Minister attending the war conferences here, who was most sympathetic but inclined to be somewhat pessimistic as to any real change of sentiment on race and colour questions in the Union for a long time.
('77', 402, 2, 11, 816136) I may say too that I have had the most cordial help and appreciation of the importance of these matters from the Dominions Office, under Sir Thomas Inskip (now Lord Caldecote, the Lord Chancellor) and the Duke of Devoshire, and Mr.Eden.

('77', 402, 2, 16, 816976) If Reitz can help in this, I am sure that he will use his influence in the right direction.
('77', 402, 3, 17, 817068) Pyarelal writes that you are wondering if I get any worthwhile news of Indian developments.
('77', 402, 3, 18, 817160) Yes, as a journalist, as an old colleague of many public men in India, and as a member of the India Conciliation Group, I get practically all that there is and am kept fully informed of what I may miss by Agatha, who has a watchful eye.
('77', 402, 3, 19, 817397) Moreover, after over thirty years of experience of the inside of Indian affairs, fortified by the observations taken during many visits to India since the historic initial one of 1909, it is not difficult for me to set things in something like a reasonable responsible perspective; though I much doubt whether you will approve of or agree with my general conclusions.
('77', 402, 4, 20, 817765) I am going to be quite frank in telling you there I disagree with what has been happening in India and the background of belief in which it has happened.

('77', 403, 1, 7, 819137) Jawaharlal could not get away from his mantram, “British imperialism” and I see that now you mutter it with equal fervour and iteration, as though it were both true and creative.
('77', 403, 2, 8, 819316) One reason why I was most anxious for you to come to the Round Table Conference (notwithstanding the conditions which you accepted upon which it was held) was that I wanted you to realise the intense and fundamental changes in public opinion here in the concept of Empire, even the most reactionary circles, which, however, did not and do not truly represent average sentiment in the country.
('77', 403, 2, 9, 819709) I was deeply disappointed that you steadily averted your mind from any real contact with that sentiment.
